Rule 19.2(g): replaced, on 1 March 2017, by section 183(a) of the Senior Courts Act 2016 (2016 No 48).
Rule 19.2(k): replaced, on 1 March 2017, by section 183(a) of the Senior Courts Act 2016 (2016 No 48).
Rule 19.2(na): inserted, on 3 November 2011, by rule 4 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2011 (SR 2011/350).
Rule 19.2(p): amended, on 13 September 2014, by rule 7 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/127).
Rule 19.2(r): replaced, on 1 December 2009, by rule 4 of the High Court (Criminal Proceeds (Recovery) Act 2009) Amendment Rules 2009 (SR 2009/313).
Rule 19.2(xa): inserted, on 1 January 2015, by rule 8 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2014 (LI 2014/348).
Rule 19.2(y): amended, on 1 July 2015, by rule 12 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2015 (LI 2015/102).
Rule 19.2(za): inserted, on 20 June 2011, by rule 20 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2010 (SR 2010/394).

prov.heading: Application of this Part to certain kinds of proceeding

para.text: This Part applies to the following kinds of proceeding:
an originating proceeding for contempt of court:
an originating proceeding for relief against forfeiture for non-payment of rent.

prov.heading: Certain directions may be sought by originating application

para.text: The following office holders may seek the directions of the court by originating application:
a liquidator:
a receiver:
a judicial manager appointed under Part 1A of the Life Insurance Act 1908:
a statutory manager appointed under the Corporations (Investigation and Management) Act 1989:
a statutory manager appointed under the Reserve Bank of New Zealand Act 1989.

prov.heading: Court may permit proceeding to be commenced by originating application

para.text: The court may, in the interests of justice, permit any proceeding not mentioned in rules 19.2 to 19.4 to be commenced by originating application.
The court’s permission may be sought without notice.
The proposed originating application must be filed with an application for permission under this rule.

prov.label: 19.5A
prov.heading: Directions as to filing of statement of claim and defence

para.text: A Judge may, by interlocutory order, on the Judge's own initiative direct the parties to file a statement of claim and a statement of defence respectively.

history.history-note: Rule 19.5A: inserted, on 11 November 2013, by rule 23 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).

prov.heading: Certain proceedings must be commenced by interlocutory application

para.text: This rule applies if—
an application under the Arbitration Act 1996 or the Personal Property Securities Act 1999 has been made by originating application; and
a party to the application wishes to make another application in respect of the same arbitration or the same security.
The other application must be made by an interlocutory application that relates to the proceeding commenced by the originating application.
This rule overrides rule 19.2(a) and (q).

A proceeding that may be commenced by originating application is commenced when the originating application is filed in the proper registry of the court, as determined in accordance with rule 5.1, or when the court gives permission under rule 19.5(1).
This rule—
prevails over rule 5.25 and Part 18; but
is subject to the special rules for company liquidations in Part 31.

prov.heading: Memorandum relating to filing and address for service

para.text: At the end of the originating application there must be a memorandum stating the matters set out in rule 5.44.
The memorandum may be in one of the paragraphs of form G 10.
The heading of a document presented for filing in a proceeding commenced by originating application must be in form G 1.
However, if there is neither a defendant nor a respondent to the proceeding, the heading must be in the following form:
In the matter of [title of enactment]
And
In the matter of an application by
[full name, place of residence, occupation] for an order that [specify nature of the order(s) being sought].

history.history-note: Rule 19.9(2): replaced, on 1 January 2011, by rule 8 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2010 (SR 2010/394).

prov.heading: Application of rules relating to interlocutory applications

para.text: The following rules concerning interlocutory applications apply with all necessary modifications to proceedings commenced by originating application:
rule 7.19 (contents, form, and filing of interlocutory application):
rule 7.20 (affidavit to be filed with application):
rule 7.21 (filing by post):
rule 7.22 (service of application and supporting affidavit):
rule 7.23 (application without notice):
rule 7.24 (notice of opposition to application):
rule 7.25 (affidavit to be filed with notice of opposition):
rule 7.26 (affidavit in reply):
rule 7.29 (rules governing affidavits):
rule 7.30 (statements of belief in affidavits):
rule 7.40 (failure to attend):
rule 7.42 (adjournment):
rule 7.45 (interlocutory orders may be made subject to conditions):
rule 7.46 (determination of application without notice):
rule 7.47 (drawing up and sealing interlocutory order).
Subclause (1) is subject to the rules in this Part.
Despite subclause (1), rule 7.45, in its application to a proceeding commenced by originating application, is subject to the Act under which the originating application is made.

prov.heading: Directions as to parties and conduct of applications

para.text: Rule 7.43A applies, with all necessary modifications, to an originating application.

history.history-note: Rule 19.11: amended, on 11 November 2013, by rule 24 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).

prov.heading: Originating applications relating to certain proceedings under Companies Act 1993

para.text: Despite rule 19.7, an originating application under section 294(5) or 295 of the Companies Act 1993 must be filed in the same office of the court in which the notice under section 294(1) of that Act was filed.
An originating application under section 299 of the Companies Act 1993 must be filed in the proper office of the court, as determined in accordance with rule 31.38.
The affidavit filed in support of an originating application under section 294(5) or 295 of the Companies Act 1993 must have attached to it a copy of the notice under section 294(1) of that Act.

prov.label: 19.12A
prov.heading: Special provisions for service of applications to remove caveats or set aside statutory demands

para.text: An originating application under section 143 of the Land Transfer Act 1952 for the removal of a caveat may be served, in accordance with rule 6.5, at the address for service stated in the caveat.

An originating application under section 290 of the Companies Act 1993 to set aside a statutory demand may be served, in accordance with rule 6.5, at the address shown in the statutory demand as the creditor's address or the address for payment.

history.history-note: Rule 19.12A: inserted, on 1 December 2009, by rule 8 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2009 (SR 2009/334).

para.text: Despite rules 7.20 and 7.25 (as applied by rule 19.10), in a proceeding commenced by originating application evidence may be taken orally on oath if the court, on application before or at the hearing, so directs.
Rule 9.74 applies to a proceeding commenced by originating application.
This Part applies to appeals to the court under any enactment other than—
the Criminal Procedure Act 2011:
the Arbitration Act 1996:
the Bail Act 2000:
appeals by way of case stated under Part 21 of these rules.

For the purposes of subclause (1)﻿(a), appeals under an enactment that incorporates provisions (whether modified or not) of the Criminal Procedure Act 2011 are not appeals under the Criminal Procedure Act 2011.
This Part applies subject to any express provision in the enactment under which the appeal is brought or sought to be brought.

history.history-note: Rule 20.1(1)﻿(a): amended, on 1 July 2013, by section 413 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2011 (2011 No 81).
Rule 20.1(2): amended, on 1 July 2013, by section 413 of the Criminal Procedure Act 2011 (2011 No 81).

para.text: In this Part,—
administrative office means the registry or office at which the decision-maker gave the decision appealed against
administrative officer means the Registrar, secretary, or other officer responsible for the administration of the administrative office
decision includes a finding, order, or judgment made by a decision-maker
decision-maker means a court, tribunal, person, or body of persons—
that exercises a power of decision from which there is, or may be, a right of appeal to the court; and
against the decision of which an appeal is brought or sought to be brought
registry means the registry of the court—
at which an appeal is required to be filed under rule 20.8(1); or
to which documents relating to an appeal are transferred under rule 20.8(3).

prov.heading: Application for leave to appeal to court

para.text: An application for leave to appeal in a case when an enactment provides that an appeal to the court against a decision may not be brought without leave must be made—
to the decision-maker or, as the case requires, the court; and
within 20 working days after the decision is given.
An application for leave to appeal must be made within 20 working days after the refusal of the decision-maker if—
an enactment provides that the court may grant leave to appeal to it against a decision after the decision-maker refuses leave; and
the decision-maker refuses leave.
The appeal must be brought—
by the date fixed when the decision-maker or the court grants leave; or
within 20 working days after the grant of leave, if the decision-maker or the court does not fix a date.
Any date fixed by the decision-maker is to be treated as a determination for the purposes of rule 7.50.

The decision-maker or, as the case requires, the court, may, on application, extend the period for bringing an application under this rule, if the enactment under which the appeal is sought to be brought—
permits the extension; or
does not limit the time prescribed for making the application.
A party may apply for the extension of a period before or after the period expires.
An application under this rule must be made on notice to every party affected by the proposed appeal and, if made to the court, must be made by interlocutory application.
In this rule, leave includes special leave.

prov.heading: Time for appeal if there is right of appeal

para.text: This rule applies if a party has a right of appeal to the court.
An appeal must be brought—
within the specified period if the enactment that confers the right of appeal specifies a period within which the appeal must be brought; or
in every other case, within 20 working days after the decision appealed against is given.
By special leave, the court may extend the time prescribed for appealing if the enactment that confers the right of appeal—
permits the extension; or
does not limit the time prescribed for bringing the appeal.
An application for an extension—
must be made by an interlocutory application on notice to every other party affected by the appeal; and
may be made before or after the expiry of the time for appealing.

prov.heading: Commencement of periods in rules 20.3 and 20.4

para.text: For the purposes of rules 20.3 and 20.4, a period begins when the decision to which it relates is given, whether or not—
reasons for the decision are given then or later; or
formal steps, such as entering or sealing the decision, are necessary or are taken after the decision is given.
An appeal is brought when the appellant—
files a notice of appeal in the court; and
files a copy of the notice of appeal in the administrative office; and
serves a copy of the notice of appeal on every other party directly affected by the appeal.
Service at the address for service stated in the proceedings to which the appeal relates is sufficient service for the purposes of subclause (1).
Despite rule 20.6(1)﻿(c), the court may dispense with service on a party of a notice of appeal on any terms the court thinks just.
Subject to any contrary enactment, a notice of appeal must be filed in—
the registry of the court nearest to the place where the hearing took place of the matter under appeal; or
if no hearing took place, in the registry of the court nearest to the place where the decision appealed against was given; or
any other registry of the court in which the parties agree that the notice of appeal may be filed.

If subclause (1)﻿(c) applies, the parties must endorse on, or file with, the notice of appeal a memorandum recording their agreement to the filing of the notice of appeal in the registry of the court in which it is filed.
The court may on application or on its own initiative in the circumstances set out in subclause (4) direct as follows:
the notice of appeal must be filed in another registry of the court; or
the documents relating to the appeal must be transferred to another registry of the court.
The circumstances are that it appears to the court that—
a notice of appeal has been filed in the wrong registry of the court; or
another registry of the court would be more appropriate.
Filing a notice of appeal in the wrong registry of the court does not invalidate an appeal.

history.history-note: Rule 20.8: replaced, on 15 May 2009, by rule 6 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2009 (SR 2009/75).

para.text: Unless the court otherwise directs, a notice of appeal must—
have a heading stating the full name and description of each party and referring to the enactment under which the appeal is brought; and
specify the decision or part of the decision appealed against; and
specify the grounds of the appeal in sufficient detail to fully inform the court, the other parties to the appeal, and the decision-maker of the issues in the appeal; and
specify the relief sought.
The notice of appeal must not name the decision-maker as a respondent.
Subclause (2) does not—
apply to appeals to the court under the Commerce Act 1986:
limit or affect rule 20.17 (which entitles a decision-maker, other than a District Court, to be represented and heard on an appeal).
An appellant may amend a notice of appeal at any time with the leave of a Judge.
If the notice of appeal does not attach a copy of the decision against which the appeal is brought, the appellant must file a copy of that decision immediately it becomes available.
An appeal does not operate as a stay—
of the proceedings appealed against; or
of enforcement of any judgment or order appealed against.
Despite subclause (1), the decision-maker or the court may, on application, do any 1 or more of the following pending determination of an appeal:
order a stay of proceedings in relation to the decision appealed against:
order a stay of enforcement of any judgment or order appealed against:
grant any interim relief.
An order made or relief granted under subclause (2) may—
relate to enforcement of the whole of a judgment or order or to a particular form of enforcement:
be subject to any conditions for the giving of security the decision-maker or the court thinks just.
A respondent wishing to contend at the hearing of an appeal that the decision appealed against should be varied must—
file a notice of cross-appeal in the registry of the court; and
file a copy of the notice in the administrative office; and
serve a copy of the notice on every other party directly affected by the cross-appeal.
A notice of cross-appeal must be filed no later than 2 working days before the case management conference relating to the appeal, except with the leave of the court.
A notice of cross-appeal must specify—
the decision or part of the decision to which the cross-appeal relates; and
the grounds of the cross-appeal in sufficient detail to fully inform the court, the other parties to the appeal, and the decision-maker of the issues in the cross-appeal; and
the relief sought.
The court may, despite a respondent’s failure to file and serve a notice of cross-appeal,—
allow the respondent to contend at the hearing that the decision appealed against should be varied; or
adjourn the hearing to allow the respondent time to file and serve a notice; or
make any other order the court thinks just, including an order for the payment of costs.
A respondent may amend a notice of cross-appeal at any time with the leave of the court.

prov.heading: Dismissal or stay or abandonment of appeal or cross-appeal

para.text: The court may, on application, dismiss or stay an appeal or a cross-appeal if the court is satisfied that the appellant or the respondent has failed to proceed with it, or has failed to comply with a direction under rule 7.5.

The appeal is taken to have been dismissed, subject to the respondent’s right to apply for an order as to costs, if the appellant signs, files, and serves on every other party a statement to the effect that the appellant abandons the appeal.

The cross-appeal is taken to have been dismissed, subject to the appellant’s right to apply for an order as to costs, if the respondent signs, files, and serves on every other party a statement to the effect that the respondent abandons the cross-appeal.
This rule applies to an appeal other than an appeal for which the appellant has been granted legal aid under the Legal Services Act 2011.
The Judge must fix security for costs at the case management conference relating to the appeal, unless the Judge considers that in the interests of justice no security is required.
The amount of security must be fixed in accordance with the following formula, unless the Judge otherwise directs:

legtable.summary: The following table contains a formula

para.text: where—
is the daily recovery rate for the proceeding as classified by the Judge under rule 14.4; and
is the number of half days estimated by the Judge as the time required for the hearing.
Security must be paid to the Registrar at the registry of the court no later than 10 working days after the case management conference, unless the Judge otherwise directs.

Except in the case of an appeal under the District Court Act 2016; and (where non-compliance with the security order results in a deemed abandonment of the appeal under section 126 of that Act), if the security is not paid within the time specified under subclause (4), the respondent may apply for an order dismissing the appeal.
The Judge must defer the fixing of security until the application for legal aid has been determined if—
an appellant has applied for legal aid under the Legal Services Act 2011; and
at the time of the case management conference, the application has not been determined.

history.history-note: Rule 20.13(1): amended, on 1 July 2013, pursuant to rule 8 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2013 (SR 2013/214).
Rule 20.13(5): amended, on 1 March 2017, by section 183(a) of the Senior Courts Act 2016 (2016 No 48).
Rule 20.13(6)﻿(a): amended, on 1 July 2013, pursuant to rule 8 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2013 (SR 2013/214).

para.text: The court may order, on application, that—
a transcript be made of all or part of the evidence given at the hearing before the decision-maker; and
the transcript be sent to the Registrar at the registry of the court.
An application under subclause (1) must be filed no later than the first of the following dates:
the date that is 20 working days after the date on which notice of appeal is filed in the court:
the working day before the date of the case management conference.
The Registrar of the court must give notice in writing to the administrative officer of any order under subclause (1).
The administrative officer must—
arrange for the transcript to be made; and
certify that the transcript is correct; and
send the certified copy of the transcript to the Registrar at the registry of the court.
The court may order, on application by the administrative officer, that a party to the appeal pay some or all of the costs of making the transcript.
An order made under subclause (1) or (5) may be made on any conditions the court thinks just.
The decision-maker must, if the court directs, provide to the Registrar at the registry of the court a report setting out—
any considerations, other than findings of fact, not set out in the decision but to which the decision-maker had regard in making the decision appealed against:
any information about the effect that the decision might have on the general administration of the enactment under which the decision was made:
any other matters relevant to the decision or to the general administration of the enactment under which the decision was made that should be drawn to the attention of the court.
The Registrar must provide a copy of the report to every party to the appeal.
Every party to the appeal is entitled to be heard, and tender evidence, on any matter referred to in the report.
Without leave, a party to an appeal may adduce further evidence on a question of fact if the evidence is necessary to determine an interlocutory application that relates to the appeal.
In all other cases, a party to an appeal may adduce further evidence only with the leave of the court.

The court may grant leave only if there are special reasons for hearing the evidence. An example of a special reason is that the evidence relates to matters that have arisen after the date of the decision appealed against and that are or may be relevant to the determination of the appeal.
Further evidence under this rule must be given by affidavit, unless the court otherwise directs.

prov.heading: Decision-maker entitled to be heard on appeal

para.text: The decision-maker is entitled to be represented and heard at the hearing of an appeal on all matters arising in it, unless—
the decision-maker is a District Court; or
the court otherwise directs.
Appeals are by way of rehearing.
After hearing an appeal, the court may do any 1 or more of the following:
make any decision it thinks should have been made:
direct the decision-maker—
to rehear the proceedings concerned; or
to consider or determine (whether for the first time or again) any matters the court directs; or
to enter judgment for any party to the proceedings the court directs:
make any order the court thinks just, including any order as to costs.
The court must state its reasons for giving a direction under subclause (1)﻿(b).
The court may give the decision-maker any direction it thinks fit relating to—
rehearing any proceedings directed to be reheard; or
considering or determining any matter directed to be considered or determined.
The court may act under subclause (1) in respect of a whole decision, even if the appeal is against only part of it.
Even if an interlocutory or similar decision in the proceedings has not been appealed against, the court—
may act under subclause (1); and
may set the interlocutory or similar decision aside; and
if it sets the interlocutory or similar decision aside, may make in its place any interlocutory or similar decision the decision-maker could have made.
The powers given by this rule may be exercised in favour of a respondent or party to the proceedings concerned, even if the respondent or party did not appeal against the decision concerned.

prov.heading: Repayment of judgment sum and interest

para.text: Subclause (2) applies when—
a party to proceedings before a decision-maker (party A) has, in accordance with a judgment or order of the decision-maker, paid an amount to another party to the proceedings (party B); and
on appeal to the court, the effect of the court’s determination is that some or all of the amount did not need to be paid.
When this subclause applies, the court—
may order party B to repay to party A some or all of the amount paid by party A; and

may also order party B to pay to party A interest, calculated in accordance with (or on a basis that ensures it does not exceed interest, calculated in accordance with) Schedule 2 of the Interest on Money Claims Act 2016, on the sum ordered to be repaid.

history.history-note: Rule 20.20(2)﻿(b): amended, on 1 January 2018, by section 29 of the Interest on Money Claims Act 2016 (2016 No 51).

prov.heading: Registrar to notify result of appeal

para.text: On the determination of an appeal, the Registrar must—
give notice in writing to the administrative officer of the result of the appeal; and
return to the administrative officer any documents and exhibits filed in accordance with any direction given at a case management conference relating to the appeal.
This rule applies when an enactment provides that a decision of the court may be appealed to the Court of Appeal with leave of the court.
If this rule applies, an application for leave to appeal must be made to the court within 20 working days after the decision is given.
A respondent who wishes to cross-appeal must apply for leave to cross-appeal within 10 working days after the date on which a copy of the application under subclause (2) is served on the respondent.
An application for leave to appeal under subclause (2) or to cross-appeal under subclause (3) must be made by interlocutory application.
This Part applies to—
appeals to the court under any Act by way of case stated for a decision on a question of law or fact (or both):
other references to the court under any Act by way of case stated for a decision on a question of law or fact (or both).
This Part does not apply to cases stated by an order under rule 10.15.
This Part applies subject to any express provision in the enactment under which the appeal is brought or sought to be brought.
The following rules apply, with all necessary modifications, to every appeal to which this Part applies:
rule 20.4(3) and (4) (extension of time for appeal):
rule 20.7 (power to dispense with service):
rule 20.10 (stay of proceedings).
In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires,—
appropriate officer, in relation to a tribunal, means the Registrar, secretary, clerk, or any other officer of the tribunal who is responsible for the administration of the tribunal
appropriate registry means the registry of the court where the appeal or reference is to be filed
decision includes any order made by a tribunal or person
tribunal includes any—
Minister of the Crown
government department or officer
any other person or body that may be required, or is authorised, by or under any Act to state or refer a case for the opinion of the court.

prov.heading: Method of commencing appeal or reference

para.text: An appellant must commence an appeal to which this Part applies by—
giving a notice of appeal to the appropriate officer of the tribunal by which the decision was made, or if there is no such officer, to the person who made the decision; and
filing a copy of the notice of appeal in the appropriate registry of the court; and
serving a copy of the notice of appeal on every party to the matter in which the decision was given (either before or immediately after the giving and filing of the notice of appeal).

References to which this Part applies that are not appeals (except for references on a tribunal’s own initiative) commence in accordance with the tribunal’s direction made on application by a party to the matter in which the question of law or fact (or both) arose.
A reference under subclause (2) must comply with rule 21.9(1).
A reference by a tribunal on its own initiative must be commenced by filing a case stated, which is signed by the chairman or other authorised officer of the tribunal, and complies with rule 21.9(1).
A notice of appeal must be given to the tribunal and filed within 20 working days after the date of the decision to which the appeal relates.
Unless otherwise provided by any enactment, every notice of appeal must specify—
the decision or the part of the decision appealed from; and
the error of law alleged by the appellant (if any); and
the question of law or fact (or both) to be resolved; and
the relief sought.
The appropriate registry in which to file a notice of appeal is—
the registry of the court nearest to the place where the matter was or is being heard; or
any other registry of the court in which the parties agree that the notice or case may be filed.
If subclause (1)﻿(a) applies, the court may direct that the notice of appeal be filed in another registry of the court if it appears to the court (on an application by a party) that—
the notice of appeal has been filed in the wrong registry of the court; or
another registry of the court would be more convenient to the parties.
If subclause (2)﻿(b) applies, the parties must endorse on or file with the notice of appeal a memorandum of their agreement.
Every person who gives a notice of appeal must, as soon as practicable after giving that notice, lodge a draft case with—
the appropriate officer of the tribunal by which the decision was made or, if there is no such officer, with the person who made the decision; and
every party to the matter in which the question of law or fact (or both) arose.
Where the case stated is a reference from a tribunal, the tribunal must serve a draft case on every party to the matter in which the question of law or fact (or both) arose.
A case must state concisely—
the circumstances relating to the matter leading to the statement of the case; and
the relevant facts as determined by the tribunal (attaching copies of documents, if any) necessary to enable the court to decide the questions; and
where appropriate, the respective contentions of the parties with reference to the questions; and
the questions on which the opinion of the court is sought.
Subclause (3) applies when a ground of appeal is—
that there was no evidence on which the tribunal could properly reach its decision, or a specified part of it; or
that the tribunal reached a wrong conclusion on a question of fact.
When this subclause applies, there must be attached to the case—
copies of the documents, affidavits, and exhibits that were placed before the tribunal; and
a copy of any evidence given at the hearing that has been transcribed.
A transcript certified as correct by or on behalf of the tribunal requires no further verification of its contents.
No document or transcript of any evidence may be attached to the case unless it is necessary for a proper determination by the court of the question of law or fact (or both) specified in the case.
The draft case may be amended by the tribunal only to correct errors of fact.
The case must be signed by or on behalf of the tribunal.

In any case stated on a question of law or fact (or both), the court may order, on any conditions it thinks just, that a transcript be made of all or any part of the evidence that was material to the issues specified in the notice of appeal if—
there has been a hearing before the tribunal by which the decision was made and the evidence given at the hearing was recorded but has not been transcribed; and
a ground of appeal is either of those referred to in rule 21.9(2).
Rule 20.14(2) to (6) applies, with all necessary modifications, in relation to an application for an order for a transcript as if the application were an application for an order under rule 20.14(1).

prov.heading: When case deemed to be stated

para.text: The appellant or the party who sought the stating of a case must ensure that, when the case has been settled and signed by or on behalf of the tribunal,—
the case is filed in the appropriate registry; and
immediately after the case has been filed in the appropriate registry, the party filing it must serve a copy on every party to the matter in which the question of law or fact (or both) arose.
A case is deemed to have been stated when a case stated has been filed.
The court may send a case back to the tribunal for amendment—
to clarify the question of law or fact (or both) on which the opinion of the court is sought; or
to provide any further information necessary to enable the court to dispose of the questions in the case stated.
The court may amend the case at the hearing.
The court may order the appellant in a case stated to give security for costs.
After hearing and determining the question of law or fact (or both) in a case stated, the court must do 1 or more of the following things:
in the case of an appeal, reverse, confirm, or amend the decision in respect of which the case was stated:
in the case of an appeal, remit the matter to the tribunal for reconsideration and decision in accordance with the opinion of the court on the question of law or fact (or both):
in every other case, remit the matter to the tribunal with the opinion of the court:
in any case, make any other order that is just.
In this Part,—
Act means the Patents Act 2013
Commissioner means the Commissioner of Patents
journal means the Journal of the Intellectual Property Office of New Zealand
report means a report by a scientific adviser
respondent’s notice means a notice given under rule 22.32
scientific adviser includes—
an accountant:
an actuary:
an architect:
an engineer:
a medical practitioner:
a person with scientific qualifications:
a surveyor:
other specially skilled persons whose opinion in relation to any matter may be of assistance to the court.

history.history-note: Rule 22.1 Act: amended, on 13 September 2014, by rule 8(1) of the High Court Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/127).
Rule 22.1 journal: amended, on 13 September 2014, by rule 8(2) of the High Court Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/127).

para.text: In a proceeding under the Act or for infringement of a patent, the court may (with or without an application) appoint an independent scientific adviser to—
assist the court; or
inquire into and report on any questions of fact or opinion that do not involve questions of law or construction.
The court must appoint an independent scientific adviser if all parties request it.

prov.heading: Nominating scientific adviser and settling questions and instructions

para.text: A scientific adviser is nominated by the court.
Questions or instructions to be submitted or given to the scientific adviser must be settled by the court.
A report by a scientific adviser must—
be made in writing to the court; and
be accompanied by the number of copies the court requires.
The court must forward copies of the report to the parties.
If a report is not accepted by all parties to a proceeding, it must be—
treated as information furnished to the court; and
given the weight the court considers appropriate.
A party may, within 10 working days of receiving a copy of a report, or within any longer time the court directs, apply for leave to cross-examine a scientific adviser on his or her report.
The court may make an order for cross-examination of the scientific adviser at the hearing.
At the hearing, the court must direct at what stage the scientific adviser will be called.
If the scientific adviser considers that an experiment or test (other than one of an insignificant nature) is necessary in order to report in a satisfactory manner, he or she must—
inform the parties; and
endeavour to get agreement between the parties on expenses for, and the persons to attend, the experiment or test.
If there is no agreement between the parties, those matters are to be determined by the court.
The court may direct a scientific adviser to make a further or supplementary report.
Rules 22.4 and 22.5 apply to further or supplementary reports.
A scientific adviser’s remuneration must be fixed by the court, and includes—
the costs of making a report; and
a proper daily fee for attendance at court.

prov.heading: Application of subpart to application under section 89

para.text: This subpart applies to an application made by a patentee under section 89 of the Act for an order to amend the patentee’s complete specification.

history.history-note: Rule 22.9 heading: amended, on 13 September 2014, by rule 9(1) of the High Court Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/127).
Rule 22.9: amended, on 13 September 2014, by rule 9(2) of the High Court Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/127).

para.text: The patentee must notify the Commissioner of an intention to make an application to amend.
A notice must be accompanied by a copy of a suitable advertisement of the proposed amendment.
The Commissioner must publish the advertisement in the journal (on 1 occasion).
The advertisement must—
contain particulars of the proposed amendment and of the patentee’s address for service within New Zealand; and
state that any person who wishes to oppose the amendment must, within 10 working days after the date of the actual issue of the journal, give written notice to the patentee.
A person giving notice under rule 22.11(3)﻿(b) is entitled to be heard, subject to any direction of the court on costs.

The patentee must, as soon as practicable after the expiration of 15 working days after the date of the issue of the journal in which an advertisement of the proposed amendment is published, proceed by way of interlocutory application.

prov.heading: Service of notice of interlocutory application

para.text: The patentee must serve notice of the interlocutory application, together with a copy of the specification certified by the Commissioner showing the proposed amendment in distinguishing ink or type, on—
the Commissioner; and
the parties; and
any person who has given notice of an intention to oppose.

prov.heading: Duty of court to give directions

para.text: On hearing the interlocutory application, the court must—
decide whether and on what terms an application is allowed to proceed (whether in relation to costs or otherwise); and

direct whether the application is to be heard on oral or affidavit evidence, and, if on affidavit evidence, fix the times within which affidavits must be filed by the parties and other persons entitled to be heard under the Act or the rules.
If the court makes an order allowing a specification to be amended,—
the patentee must immediately lodge a copy of the order with the Commissioner; and
the Commissioner must advertise the order on 1 occasion in the journal and otherwise as the court may direct.

A patentee must, if required by the court or the Commissioner, leave a new specification and drawings as amended and prepared under the Patents Regulations 2014 at the Intellectual Property Office of New Zealand.

history.history-note: Rule 22.16(2): amended, on 13 September 2014, by rule 10 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/127).

para.text: An application to the court to revoke a patent under section 112 of the Act (not being an application made in the course of a proceeding) must be by way of an originating application.
The originating application must be filed in the registry of the court at Wellington (unless the court otherwise directs).

history.history-note: Rule 22.17(1): amended, on 13 September 2014, by rule 11 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/127).

para.text: The respondent is entitled—
to begin and give evidence in support of the patent; and
to reply, if the applicant gives evidence impeaching the validity of the patent.
This rule has effect despite rule 10.10.

prov.heading: Particulars if validity of patent disputed

para.text: Particulars of an objection to the validity of a patent must—
be delivered with—
an application for revocation under section 112 of the Act; or
a defence in a proceeding for infringement of a patent; or
a counterclaim for revocation under section 147 of the Act; and
include the grounds on which the validity of the patent is disputed; and
include particulars clearly stating issues intended to be raised.

history.history-note: Rule 22.19: replaced, on 13 September 2014, by rule 12 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/127).

prov.heading: Particulars if want of novelty alleged

para.text: The particulars of an objection on the basis of want of novelty must state the time and place of the alleged previous knowledge, publication, or use.
The particulars of an objection on the basis that the invention has been used prior to the date of the patent must—
state the name and address of the alleged prior user and the place of prior use; and
state whether the prior use is alleged to have continued to the date of the patent, and, if not, the earliest and latest dates on which the prior use is alleged to have taken place; and
contain a description (accompanied by drawings, if necessary) sufficient to identify the alleged prior use; and
if the use relates to machinery or apparatus, specify whether it is in existence and where it may be inspected.

Evidence that exists at the date of delivery of the particulars about machinery or apparatus in relation to which prior use is alleged is not able to be received, unless it is proved that the party relying on the prior use has,—
if the machinery or apparatus is in that party’s own possession, offered an inspection of it; or
if the machinery or apparatus is not in that party’s own possession, used best endeavours to obtain an inspection of it for the other parties to the proceeding.
A party that intends to dispute the validity of a patent in a proceeding must—
give notice of that intention to the Solicitor-General at least 15 working days before the hearing; and
supply the Solicitor-General with a copy of papers filed in the proceeding by that party or papers filed by any other party that the Solicitor-General requires.
In a proceeding for infringement of a patent, the plaintiff must—
deliver particulars of the breaches relied on with the plaintiff’s statement of claim; and
state which aspects of the specification of the patent are alleged to be infringed; and
give at least 1 instance of each type of infringement.

history.history-note: Rule 22.23: revoked, on 13 September 2014, by rule 13 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/127).

para.text: No person may be heard or adduce evidence in support of an alleged infringement, objection, or defence so far as it relates to matters that are not specified in, or are at variance with, the particulars that person has delivered.
Despite subclause (1), the court may grant leave on terms it considers appropriate.
Particulars filed in the court under these rules may be amended by leave of the court on terms the court considers just.
Further and better particulars may at any time be ordered by the court.
This rule has effect despite rule 7.77.
Part 20 applies to an appeal under the Act, unless modified by or inconsistent with this Part or the Act.

prov.heading: Method and time of bringing appeal

para.text: A person who wishes to appeal from a decision of the Commissioner in relation to which a right of appeal is given by the Act must file a notice of appeal in the court.
The notice of appeal must be filed within 20 working days after the date of the Commissioner’s decision.
Other than with the leave of the court, an appeal must not be entertained unless notice of appeal has been given within the 20-working-day period.
A notice of appeal must state—
the decision or part of the decision appealed against; and
any error of law alleged; and
any question of law to be resolved; and
the grounds of the appeal (specified with reasonable particularity in order to give the court and the other parties full information about the issues involved); and
the relief sought.
Only grounds stated in the notice of appeal may be allowed to be taken by the appellant at the hearing, unless the court grants leave to do otherwise on terms it considers appropriate.
An appellant must, within 5 working days of filing a notice of appeal, serve a copy of it on—
the Commissioner; and
any other party to the proceeding before the Commissioner.
On receiving notice of an appeal, the Commissioner must immediately transmit all papers relating to the subject matter of the appeal to the court.

A respondent who has not appealed a decision of the Commissioner, but who wishes to contend on appeal that the decision be varied (in any event or in the event of the appeal being allowed in whole or in part)—
must give notice stating the grounds of the contention and the relief sought by the respondent; and
need not file a further notice of appeal.
A respondent who wishes to argue that a decision of the Commissioner be affirmed on grounds other than those set out in the decision must give notice of those grounds of contention.
A respondent’s notice must be sent to the Commissioner, the appellant, and every other party to the proceedings before the Commissioner—
within 20 working days after the date of the receipt of the notice of appeal by the respondent; or
within any longer period the court directs.
A party sending a respondent’s notice must, within 5 working days after the date of the service of the notice on the appellant, give 2 copies of the notice to the court.

If more than 1 party files a notice of appeal, any party (whether or not that party has filed a notice of appeal) may file a respondent’s notice in respect of a notice of appeal given by any other party.
An appeal is by way of rehearing.
The evidence used on appeal must be the same as that used before the Commissioner.
No further evidence may be given, except with the leave of the court.

prov.heading: Proceeding heard and determined in public

para.text: A proceeding under the Act or for infringement of a patent must be heard and determined in public unless the court directs that it must be heard in private.

Despite subclause (1), a proceeding relating to a decision of the Commissioner in a case in which the complete specification of the patent application has not been published must be heard and determined in private unless the court directs that it must be heard in public.
A direction given by the court (on its own initiative or on the application of a party to a proceeding) may relate to the whole proceeding or a specified part of it.
Rules about the filing of documentary evidence in proceedings before the Commissioner apply to documentary evidence filed on an appeal.
At the request of a party, the court may order that a person who has made a statutory declaration or sworn an affidavit in the matter to which the appeal relates attend for cross-examination.

A party that requires a witness to attend for cross-examination must pay the witness the appropriate fees, allowances, and travelling expenses under the appropriate scales specified in the Schedule of the Witnesses and Interpreters Fees Regulations 1974.

In a proceeding for infringement of a patent, no costs are allowed to the parties who deliver particulars of breaches or of objection in respect of any issues raised in those particulars and relating to that patent unless the issues or particulars are certified by the court as—
proved; or
reasonable and proper.

subpart.heading: Enforcement under Reciprocal Enforcement of Judgments Act 1934

para.text: This subpart applies to the enforcement of judgments under the Act.
With the exception of subclause (3), this subpart does not apply to, and does not affect—
the enforcement of judgments at common law by a proceeding commenced under Part 5 or 12; or
the filing of memorials, and subsequent enforcement, of judgments obtained out of New Zealand (see section 172 of the Senior Courts Act 2016).

An application to the court or a Judge under section 172(5) of the Senior Courts Act 2016 for an order that the person against whom the judgment was obtained show cause why enforcement process should not issue must be made by originating application under Part 19.
In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires,—
Act means the Reciprocal Enforcement of Judgments Act 1934
application for registration means an application made under section 4 of the Act
foreign judgment means any judgment to which, under section 3, 3A, or 3B of the Act, Part 1 of the Act for the time being applies
general rules means the rules comprised in the other Parts of these rules.
Unless the context otherwise requires, expressions not defined in this subpart but defined in the Act have the meanings so defined.

history.history-note: Rule 23.1(2)﻿(b): amended, on 1 March 2017, by section 183(a) of the Senior Courts Act 2016 (2016 No 48).
Rule 23.1(3): amended, on 1 March 2017, by section 183(a) of the Senior Courts Act 2016 (2016 No 48).

para.text: The general rules apply except so far as they are modified by or are inconsistent with this subpart.

prov.heading: Subpart subject to Orders in Council

para.text: This subpart has effect subject to provisions in Orders in Council made under section 3, 3A, or 3B of the Act declared by those Orders in Council to be necessary for giving effect to any agreement made by or on behalf of the Government of New Zealand in relation to matters in respect of which there is power to make rules of court for the purposes of Part 1 of the Act.
An application for registration must be made by originating application in form G 30, and Part 19 applies except so far as it is modified by or inconsistent with this subpart.
The application may be made without notice to the judgment debtor.

history.history-note: Rule 23.4(2): amended, on 1 September 2017, by rule 23 of the High Court Rules 2016 Amendment Rules (No 2) 2017 (LI 2017/191).

para.text: The heading to each document filed in an application for registration must—
include both a reference to the Act and a reference to the judgment sought to be enforced; and
specify, in relation to the judgment, both the court in which it was given and the parties to the judgment.

An application for registration must be filed in the registry of the court in which the defendant would have been required to file that defendant’s statement of defence had the proceeding been commenced by way of proceeding on the foreign judgment and not by way of application for registration.
Every application for registration must be supported by 1 or more affidavits.
The foreign judgment, or a verified or certified or otherwise duly authenticated copy of it, must be attached as an exhibit to an affidavit filed in support of the application for registration.
If the judgment is expressed in a language other than English, a translation of the judgment in English must be filed.
Any such translation must be verified by the affidavit of a person qualified as a translator from that language.

prov.heading: Judicial notice of authentication of judgment

para.text: Judicial notice must be taken of any seal or signature by which a copy of a foreign judgment is verified and which purports to be—
the seal of the court in which the judgment was given or of a Judge or a Registrar or similar officer of the court; or
the signature of a Judge or Registrar or similar officer of that court.

prov.heading: Evidence of exchange rates and interest

para.text: The affidavit or affidavits filed in support of the application for registration of a money judgment must include,—
when the application does not state that the judgment creditor wishes the judgment to be registered in the currency in which it is expressed,—
the rate of exchange prevailing on the day of the application between New Zealand currency and the currency in which the sum payable under the judgment is expressed:
the amount that the sum payable under the judgment represents in New Zealand currency calculated at that rate:
the rate of interest (if any) carried by the judgment by the law of the country under which it is given:
the amount of interest that, by that law, will have become due under the judgment up to the time of the application, expressed,—
when the application does not state that the judgment creditor wishes the judgment to be registered in the currency in which it is expressed, in New Zealand currency calculated under paragraph (a):
when the application states that the judgment is to be registered in the currency in which it is expressed, in that currency.
An affidavit filed in support of the application for registration must state, to the best of the information and belief of the person,—
that the applicant is entitled to enforce the judgment; and
either—
that, at the date of the application, the judgment has not been satisfied; or
that, at the date of the application, the judgment has been partly satisfied; and
if, at the date of the application, the judgment has been partly satisfied, the balance remaining payable or other action required to be taken to satisfy the judgment at that date; and
that, at the date of the application, the judgment can be enforced in the country of the original court; and
that, if the judgment were registered, the registration would not be, or be liable to be, set aside under section 6 of the Act; and
the full name, title, trade, or business, and the usual or last known place of abode or of business of the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor respectively.
The person making the affidavit must specify in that affidavit the source of the person’s information and the grounds for his or her belief.
The application for registration must be supported by whatever other evidence may be required, having regard,—
in the case of a money judgment of a superior court, to the Order in Council under section 3 of the Act:
in the case of a money judgment of an inferior court, to the Order in Council under section 3A of the Act:
in the case of a non-money judgment of a superior court, to the Order in Council under section 3B(1) of the Act:
in the case of a non-money judgment of an inferior court, to the Order in Council under section 3B(2) of the Act.
When—
a foreign judgment is in respect of different matters; and
if some parts of the foreign judgment had been contained in separate judgments, those judgments could not properly have been registered,—
the application for registration must specify, and the order giving leave to register the foreign judgment must be limited to, the parts that are entitled to registration.

The court may, on any application for registration, order the judgment creditor to give security for the costs of the judgment debtor in opposing the application or in applying to set aside the registration.
The order giving leave to register a judgment or part of a judgment—
must state the period, being a period computed from the date of service of notice of registration, within which an application may be made to set aside the registration; and
must prohibit enforcement of the judgment until after the expiration of the period stated in paragraph (a).
Unless the court otherwise orders, the period stated under subclause (1)﻿(a) must be the same as would apply under the general rules to the filing of a statement of defence in a proceeding.

The court may, on an application made at any time while it remains competent for any party to apply to have the registration set aside, grant an extension of the period (either as originally fixed or as subsequently extended) during which an application to have the judgment set aside may be made.
It is not necessary to serve an order made under subclause (1) on the judgment debtor.
The registration of every judgment ordered to be registered under the Act must be effected by entry of particulars in an appropriate record book kept by the Registrar.
The record book must state—
the date of the order for registration:
the name, title, trade, or business of the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor:
the usual or last known place of abode or business of the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor:
in the case of a money judgment, the sum payable under the judgment, expressed,—
when the application states that the judgment creditor wishes the judgment to be registered in the currency in which it is expressed, in that currency; or
in any other case, as if it were for an equivalent amount in New Zealand currency, based on the rate of exchange prevailing on the day of the application for registration:
the interest (if any), up to the time of registration, for which the judgment is registered:
where the judgment is a non-money judgment, particulars of the judgment:
the costs allowed of and incidental to registration:
any special directions contained in the order for registration:
the particulars of any action taken to enforce the judgment.
The date of the order for registration and the date of the registration are to be treated as the date when the originating application was filed.
Subclause (1) is subject to a court order.
Notice in writing of the registration of a foreign judgment in New Zealand must be served on the judgment debtor.
The notice must be served personally in accordance with the general rules unless some other mode of service is ordered by the court.
Despite rule 6.28, if the judgment debtor is out of New Zealand, the notice may be served without the leave of the court.
The notice of registration must state—
full particulars of—
the judgment registered; and
the order for registration; and
any special direction contained in the order for registration; and
whether the notice is issued by the judgment creditor or by a solicitor on behalf of the judgment creditor; and
an address for service; and
subject to subclause (2), the right of the judgment debtor to apply, on the grounds appearing in the Act, to have the registration set aside; and
in accordance with the terms of the order giving leave to register, within what period from the date of service of the notice an application to set aside may be made.
Subclause (1)﻿(d) does not require the notice to set out the grounds on which the registration can be set aside.
An application to set aside the registration of a foreign judgment must be made by interlocutory application.

On any such application, the court may direct that an issue between the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor must be stated and tried and may give such directions in relation to the trial of the issue as may be necessary.

If, whether under the Act or under this subpart, any question arises about whether a judgment to which Part 1 of the Act applies can be enforced in the country of the original court, or what interest is payable under any judgment under the law of that country, that question must be determined in accordance with,—
in the case of a money judgment of a superior court, the Order in Council under section 3 of the Act:
in the case of a money judgment of an inferior court, the Order in Council under section 3A of the Act:
in the case of a non-money judgment of a superior court, the Order in Council under section 3B(1) of the Act:
in the case of a non-money judgment of an inferior court, the Order in Council under section 3B(2) of the Act.
A registered judgment must not be enforced at any time in—
the period specified in the order for registration; or
any extension of the period specified in the order for registration; or
the period between the filing and the disposal of any application to set aside the registration.
In every case the fact and date of service of the notice of registration must be proved by an affidavit.
The form of an enforcement process within the meaning of rule 17.3 issued on a foreign judgment registered under the Act must—
specify the sum awarded, or the order or other relief granted; and
state the name and address of the judgment creditor; and
name the judgment debtor against whom the judgment was obtained; and
name the court in which the judgment was obtained and the date of that judgment; and
certify that the judgment has been duly registered in the High Court pursuant to Part 1 of the Reciprocal Enforcement of Judgments Act 1934.

An application under section 11 of the Act for a certified copy of a judgment obtained in the court must be made by application without notice filed in the registry of the court in which the judgment was sealed.
The application must be supported by the affidavit of the judgment creditor or the judgment creditor’s solicitor, and that affidavit must—
give particulars of the proceeding in which the judgment was sealed; and
attach—
a copy of the statement of claim by which the proceeding was instituted; and
evidence of the service of the statement of claim upon the judgment debtor or of appearance by the judgment debtor in the proceeding; and
copies of the pleadings, if any, in the proceeding; and
verify the copies of evidence attached to it in accordance with paragraph (b); and
state the grounds on which the judgment was based; and
state whether the judgment debtor did or did not object to the jurisdiction, and, if so, on what grounds; and
state—
that the judgment is not subject to any stay of execution or of enforcement; and
that no notice of appeal against it has been given; and
whether the time for appealing has expired; and
state the rate at which the judgment carries interest.
It is not necessary to seal any order made on an application under rule 23.24; instead, the Registrar must issue to the judgment creditor—
a copy of the judgment sealed with the seal of the court, which copy must be certified by the Registrar—
to be a true copy; and
to be issued in accordance with section 11 of the Act; and
a separate certificate under the seal of the court in which the Registrar must certify—
the matters stated in the affidavit filed in accordance with rule 23.24(2); and
any other particulars it is necessary to give to the court or tribunal in which enforcement of the judgment will be sought.
In giving a certificate under subclause (1)﻿(b) the Registrar is entitled to rely on the affidavit filed under rule 23.24(2) and the documents attached to it.

para.text: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, Act means the Insolvency Act 2006.
In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, expressions defined in the Act and used but not defined in this Part have the meanings given by the Act.
Subclause (1) does not apply to subpart 15 (cross-border proceedings).
This Part applies to matters arising under the Act or Part 4 of the Administration Act 1969, and to proceedings relating to them in the court, whenever commenced.

prov.heading: Application of general rules and practice of court

para.text: The other Parts of these rules and the general practice of the court apply when this Part applies, unless they are modified by or inconsistent with the Act or this Part.
The prescribed forms must be used whenever appropriate.
If a form has not been prescribed for an application, it must be an interlocutory application, and an order made on that application must be in the form prescribed for an interlocutory order.
If subclause (2) does not apply, the parties may frame a form for the special purpose of the particular case or the court may frame the form.
If no form is prescribed, a notice must contain sufficient details to inform the recipient fairly of its substance.
A warrant to search for and seize a bankrupt’s property under section 150 or 151 of the Act must be in form B 7.

prov.heading: General requirements of documents filed in court

para.text: Every document filed must—
comply with the rules in subpart 3 of Part 5 so far as they are applicable and with any necessary modifications; and
be headed by the words In the matter of the Insolvency Act 2006, and in the matter of the bankruptcy (or proposal, as the case may be) of.

An advertisement of a notice or proceeding that is published in a newspaper circulating in the area in which the proceeding is pending must comply with the advertising requirements of the Act or this Part.

prov.heading: Discretion of court as to method of taking evidence

para.text: Unless otherwise provided in this Part, the court may, in any proceeding, take all or any part of the evidence orally or by written interrogatories or on affidavit or by commission, as the court thinks just.
A request for the issue of a bankruptcy notice must be in form B 1.
The Registrar may approve the issue of a bankruptcy notice if—
the request is founded on a judgment or order of a court; and
the Registrar has no knowledge that payment of the debt has occurred.
A bankruptcy notice must be in form B 2 and a certified copy of the judgment or order on which the bankruptcy notice is based must be attached to it.
The bankruptcy notice must state the amount of any costs claimed.

prov.heading: Service of bankruptcy notice in New Zealand

para.text: A bankruptcy notice that is to be served in New Zealand must be served within 6 months from the date of its issue.
The creditor may before or after the expiry of the period referred to in subclause (1) apply to the court for an order extending the period of service.
The court may extend the period for service for a further 3 months from the expiry of the period referred to in subclause (1) if the court is satisfied that—
reasonable efforts have been made to effect service; or
for any other good reason an extension of the period for service is desirable.
A bankruptcy notice must be served in accordance with Part 6 (Service).

history.history-note: Rule 24.9(1): amended, on 11 November 2013, by rule 25(1) of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).
Rule 24.9(2): replaced, on 11 November 2013, by rule 25(2) of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).
Rule 24.9(3): replaced, on 11 November 2013, by rule 25(2) of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).
Rule 24.9(4): inserted, on 11 November 2013, by rule 25(3) of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 3) 2013 (SR 2013/425).

para.text: If an application to set aside a bankruptcy notice cannot be heard until after the expiration of the time specified in the notice as the day on which the act of bankruptcy will be complete, the time is treated as extended until the application has been determined.
An act of bankruptcy is not committed by reason only of non-compliance with the notice until the application has been determined.
A creditor’s application for adjudication must be commenced by filing an originating application in form B 3.
Part 19 applies to adjudication proceedings but, in case of any conflict, is overridden by this Part.
An affidavit in form B 4 and a summons to debtor in form B 5 must be filed (in duplicate) with a creditor’s application.
A summons must also state the amount of any costs claimed.
An order of adjudication made on the application must be in form B 16.

history.history-note: Rule 24.11(5): inserted, on 1 January 2011, by rule 9 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2010 (SR 2010/394).

para.text: A creditor’s application must be verified by affidavit of the creditor or some other person having knowledge of the facts.

prov.heading: Where application for adjudication to be filed

para.text: An application for adjudication must be filed,—

if the debtor is resident in New Zealand, in the registry of the High Court nearest by the most practicable route to the place in which the debtor has resided or carried on business for the longest period during the 6 months immediately before the time when the application is filed:
if the debtor is in custody, in the registry of the High Court nearest by the most practicable route to the place in which the debtor is in custody:

if the debtor is absent from New Zealand or the applying creditor cannot ascertain the debtor’s place of residence, in the registry of the High Court nearest by the most practicable route to the place in which the applying creditor resides or carries on business:
if a debtor has never been resident in New Zealand, in the registry of the High Court nearest by the most practicable route to the place in which the applying creditor resides or carries on business:
if any act of bankruptcy relied on by the applying creditor is specified in sections 20 and 21 of the Act, in any registry of the court.

prov.heading: Registrar to fix hearing date for creditor’s application

para.text: The Registrar must fix a hearing date for the application and insert the date in the summons to the debtor before releasing the summons to the creditor for service.
If the application and summons have not been served, the Registrar may, from time to time, alter the hearing date.

prov.heading: Court may alter hearing date for creditor’s application

para.text: If it is proved to the court’s satisfaction that the debtor has absconded or there is any other good reason, the court may, on any terms it thinks just, hear the creditor’s application on any date the court considers expedient.

prov.heading: Service of creditor’s application on debtor

para.text: A copy of the creditor’s application and the summons to the debtor must be served on the debtor at least 10 working days before the hearing of the creditor’s application.
If the debtor dies before service of the creditor’s application and summons, the court may order service to be effected on the debtor’s administrator or any other person as it thinks just.

prov.heading: Service of creditor’s application on trustee or supervisor

para.text: A copy of the creditor’s application and the summons to the debtor must be served personally on the trustee or supervisor, as the case may be,—

if the act of bankruptcy alleged is that the debtor has made a disposition of all or substantially all of the debtor’s property to a trustee for the benefit of all or any of the debtor’s creditors; or

if, at the time of the filing of the application, a proposal under subpart 2 of Part 5 of the Act has been approved by the court or a summary instalment order has been made under subpart 3 of Part 5 of the Act.
The documents set out in subclause (1) must be served at least 10 working days before the hearing of the creditor’s application.

prov.heading: Debtor’s notice of intention to oppose adjudication

para.text: A debtor who intends to oppose the making of an order of adjudication must, by 1 pm on the last working day before the hearing of the creditor’s application,—
file a notice of opposition in form B 6, together with an affidavit in support of the opposition; and
serve a copy of those documents on the applicant creditor.
Unless the court otherwise directs, an applicant creditor’s evidence of a debt, an act of bankruptcy, or any other material statements may be given by affidavit.
The affidavit must be sworn by or on behalf of the applicant creditor at least 3 working days before the date of the hearing of the application.

prov.heading: Applicant creditor’s solicitor’s certificate as to unpaid debt

para.text: A certificate by the applicant creditor’s solicitor to the effect that, after having made due inquiries, the solicitor is satisfied that the debt remains unpaid, may be accepted by the court as sufficient prima facie evidence that the debt remains unpaid.

prov.heading: Death of debtor against whom application filed

para.text: If a debtor against whom a bankruptcy application is filed dies, the application must, unless the court otherwise orders, be continued as if the debtor were alive.

prov.heading: Applicant to deposit sum for Official Assignee’s expenses

para.text: The person who has applied for an order appointing the Official Assignee to be a receiver and manager of all or any part of the debtor’s estate must, before the order is made, deposit with the Official Assignee any sum that the court directs for the Official Assignee’s expenses.

prov.heading: Official Assignee may seek additional sum where original deposit insufficient

para.text: If the sum deposited for the Official Assignee’s expenses under rule 24.22 is insufficient, the person who paid the deposit must deposit with the Official Assignee any additional sum that the court may, on the application of the Official Assignee, from time to time direct.

If the additional sum is not deposited within 24 hours after the making of the order, the Official Assignee may apply to have the order appointing the Official Assignee as receiver and manager discharged by the court.

prov.heading: Notification of order appointing Official Assignee as receiver and manager

para.text: The Registrar must, immediately after the order appointing the Official Assignee as receiver and manager has been made, forward 2 copies of the order to the Official Assignee.
If the debtor is in New Zealand, the Official Assignee must cause a copy of the order appointing the Official Assignee as receiver and manager to be served on the debtor.
The Official Assignee must advertise the Official Assignee’s appointment as receiver and manager within 5 working days after the making of the order.
The order referred to in this rule must be in form B 17.

history.history-note: Rule 24.24(4): inserted, on 1 January 2011, by rule 10 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2010 (SR 2010/394).

prov.heading: Repayment of deposits after order of adjudication

para.text: If an order of adjudication is made after the Official Assignee is appointed receiver and manager, the Official Assignee must repay to the creditor the deposits made under rules 24.22 and 24.23 out of the proceeds of the estate.

If there are insufficient proceeds in the estate to pay the Official Assignee’s fees and expenses as receiver and manager, the Official Assignee may keep all or any part of the deposits as payment of those fees and expenses.

prov.heading: Dismissal of application after order appointing Official Assignee as manager and receiver

para.text: If, after an order has been made appointing the Official Assignee as receiver and manager, the application upon which the order was made is dismissed,—
the court must, on an application made within 15 working days from the date of the dismissal, make an order relating to any damages or claim arising out of the Official Assignee’s appointment; and
the court may make any other order it thinks just.
A creditor who intends to make an application under section 147 of the Act must give at least 10 working days' notice of that intention to the Official Assignee and to the bankrupt.

If the Official Assignee or a creditor applies for an order under section 147 of the Act, the Official Assignee must prepare a report as to the circumstances of the bankruptcy, the bankrupt’s conduct, and the bankrupt’s earning power, responsibilities, and prospects.

At least 5 working days before the time fixed for the hearing, the Official Assignee must lodge the report in the court, and forward a copy to the bankrupt, and to the applicant, if the applicant is a creditor.

prov.heading: Official Assignee to notify employer, etc, about proposed assignment or charge

para.text: If it is proposed that an order be made assigning to, or charging in favour of, the Official Assignee any money due or becoming due to the bankrupt by way of wages or salary or from any other source,—
the Official Assignee must notify the employer or other person against whom the assignment or charge is proposed; and
the person who is notified is entitled to appear and be heard.

prov.heading: Official Assignee to serve order of assignment, etc

para.text: The Official Assignee must serve a duplicate of any order assigning or charging in favour of the Official Assignee any money due or becoming due to the bankrupt on the employer or other person against whom the assignment or charge was given.
The Official Assignee may apply to the court to approve a composition (whether or not the Official Assignee reports in favour of it) if—
the creditors have passed a confirming resolution in relation to the composition; and
the bankrupt does not, within 3 working days from the date of the confirmation, apply to the court for approval of the composition.
The Official Assignee is not, by making the application, treated as approving the composition.

prov.heading: Notice to Official Assignee of application to approve composition

para.text: Any person, other than the Official Assignee, who applies to the court to approve a composition must, at least 10 working days before the day appointed for hearing the application, serve notice of the application on the Official Assignee.

prov.heading: Notice of application to approve composition

para.text: If an application is made to the court to approve a composition, the Official Assignee must, at least 5 working days before the day appointed for hearing the application, send notice of the application to every creditor whose debt has been proved.

prov.heading: Official Assignee to account when composition approved

para.text: If a composition is approved by the court, the Official Assignee must account to the bankrupt, or, as the case may be, to the trustee.

prov.heading: Applications by Official Assignee for cancellation of irregular transactions or retransfer of property or payment of value

para.text: An application to the court by the Official Assignee under section 206 of the Act (for the cancellation of an irregular transaction) or under section 207 of the Act (for the retransfer of property or payment of value) must be made by originating application under Part 19.
An application under section 206 must be in form B 14.
An application under section 207 must be in form B 15.

prov.heading: Filing and service of objection to discharge

para.text: An objection to a discharge under section 292 of the Act is entered by filing an objection in form B 8.
A creditor who enters an objection to a discharge must serve the objection on the Official Assignee.

prov.heading: Service, etc, of notice of application for discharge

para.text: At least 20 working days before the hearing date, the bankrupt must—
serve on the Official Assignee, and every creditor whose debt has been proved, notice of application for discharge under section 294 of the Act; and
cause notice of the application and the hearing date to be advertised.

history.history-note: Rule 24.37: amended, on 1 July 2015, by rule 13 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2015 (LI 2015/102).

para.text: At least 10 working days before the hearing date, the Official Assignee must—
lodge in the court a copy of the Official Assignee’s report under section 296 of the Act; and
serve a copy of the report on the bankrupt and all creditors known to the Official Assignee.

history.history-note: Rule 24.38: amended, on 1 July 2015, by rule 14 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2015 (LI 2015/102).

para.text: A creditor who intends to oppose the discharge of a bankrupt on grounds other than those specified in the Official Assignee’s report must file and serve on the Official Assignee and the bankrupt a notice of the creditor’s intended opposition and the grounds of opposition not less than 5 working days before the hearing.

history.history-note: Rule 24.39: amended, on 1 July 2015, by rule 15 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2015 (LI 2015/102).

prov.heading: Conditions affecting salary, etc, after order of discharge

para.text: The Official Assignee must notify the bankrupt’s employer of the Official Assignee’s intention to ask the court to impose a condition that affects any salary or wages that may, after the date of the order of discharge, become due to the bankrupt.
The Official Assignee must notify the employer of an order made under section 298 of the Act before receiving payment of any salary or wages.

prov.heading: Annulment of adjudication to be advertised

para.text: The Official Assignee must immediately cause a notice of an order annulling an adjudication to be advertised.

prov.heading: Proposal and statement of affairs and affidavit

para.text: A proposal under subpart 2 of Part 5 of the Act must be in form B 9 and must be accompanied by a statement of affairs and affidavit in form B 10.
The trustee must file a report in form B 11 with the application for approval under section 333 of the Act.

prov.heading: Application for order to administer under Part 6 of Act

para.text: An application for an order to administer under Part 6 of the Act must be by originating application.
