Notice of an application under section 381 of the Act must be given by serving on the administrator, or, if no administrator has been appointed, on those persons that the court directs, a copy of the application together with a copy of any supporting affidavit.
The court may, within such time as the court requires, direct the administrator to file the account in form B 12 if—
an application is made by a creditor, or any person beneficially interested, after a request has been made to an administrator; and
the administrator, having been requested in writing to apply, has failed to make an application within 15 working days after receiving the request.

prov.heading: Duty of Registrar when order made

para.text: If an order is made under section 379 or 381 of the Act, the Registrar must send to the appointee and to the Commissioner of Inland Revenue a copy of the order and of the account specified in section 380(3) of the Act.

prov.heading: Duty of administrator when order made

para.text: If an order has been made under section 379 or 381 of the Act,—
the administrator must immediately send an account of the administrator’s dealings and administration of the deceased estate to the appointee; and
the administrator must, at the same time, provide whatever particulars of the affairs of the deceased are required by the appointee.

prov.heading: Person who has intermeddled in estate may be ordered to give particulars

para.text: The court may, on an appointee’s application, direct that an account be made, verified, and given by any person the court considers has administered or otherwise intermeddled with all or any part of the deceased’s property, if—
an order has been made under section 379 or 381 of the Act; and
it appears to the court that no administrator exists and the appointee is unable to find any person willing to give the particulars required by rule 24.47.
A certificate by Public Trust or the Māori Trustee recording an election to administer an insolvent estate under Part 6 of the Act must be in form B 13.

prov.heading: Applications to vary or discharge order or decision of Registrar or District Court Judge

para.text: An application to the court under section 414 of the Act to vary or discharge the order or decision of a Registrar or District Court Judge under section 413 of the Act must be filed,—
if it is made by a party who was present or represented when the order was made or the decision given, within 5 working days after the making of the order or the giving of the decision; or
if it is made by a party who was not then present or represented, within 5 working days after the receipt by the party of notice of the order or decision.
The application does not stay proceedings unless a Judge, the Registrar, or the District Court Judge otherwise orders.
The Court of Appeal (Civil) Rules 2005, so far as they are applicable and with any necessary modifications, apply to appeals to the Court of Appeal under section 414 of the Act.
The Official Assignee of the bankrupt’s property is a party to an appeal.

prov.heading: Applications to court by Official Assignee

para.text: An application by the Official Assignee to the court may be made personally, by counsel, or by any agent duly appointed under paragraph (t) of Schedule 1 of the Act.
Unless the court otherwise directs, the Official Assignee is not personally liable for costs if—
proceedings are brought against the Official Assignee representing the estate of the bankrupt; or
the Official Assignee is made a party to a proceeding on the application of another party.

If, under the Act, an application relating to bankruptcy may be filed in a District Court, the Registrar of that court must forward to the nearest High Court a certified copy of the decision of that court.
The certified copy of the decision of the District Court must be filed by the Registrar and forms part of the proceedings of the High Court.
In this subpart, unless the context otherwise requires, Act means the Insolvency (Cross-border) Act 2006.
Unless the context otherwise requires, expressions defined in Schedule 1 of the Act have, in this subpart, the meanings so defined.
In this subpart, references to articles are references to articles in Schedule 1 of the Act.

prov.heading: Applications for recognition of foreign proceedings

para.text: An application by a foreign representative under article 15(1) must be made by originating application under Part 19.
In addition to complying with the requirements of article 15, the application must—

be supported by an affidavit verifying the statement referred to in article 15(3) (identifying all foreign proceedings in respect of the debtor that are known to the foreign representative) or by other sworn evidence acceptable to the court:

be served, in accordance with Part 6 of these rules, on the debtor or a New Zealand agent or representative of the debtor unless a Judge directs that the application may in all the circumstances proceed without that service.
A foreign representative who has filed an application under subclause (1) may apply without notice for relief of a provisional nature under article 19(1).

A New Zealand agent or representative of the debtor served under rule 24.56(2)﻿(b), must, as a condition of being treated as a respondent to the application under Part 19, provide evidence of that agency or representation to the court’s satisfaction.

The foreign representative must, when filing an application under rule 24.56(1) or within 25 working days after the date of filing, file an application for directions as to service under rule 18.7 and the Judge may give directions as to service and make any incidental orders considered just.

An application for modification or termination of recognition under article 17(5) must be made by originating application served on the parties and any other persons who were directed to be served before the recognition order under article 17(1) was made.
The foreign representative may apply by interlocutory application for appropriate relief under article 21(1).
An application under subclause (1) must be served on—
any other parties to the application under rule 24.56:
persons directed to be served under rule 24.56:
any judgment creditor carrying on business, or resident, or having a registered office, in New Zealand.

The foreign representative or a person affected by relief granted under article 19 and rule 24.56(3), or under article 21 and rule 24.58, may apply by interlocutory application for an order modifying or terminating the relief granted.
The statutory manager may apply by interlocutory application under article 22(4) to terminate relief granted under article 19 and rule 24.56(3), or under article 21 and rule 24.58.

prov.heading: Appointment of administrator under section 239L of Companies Act 1993

para.text: An application by a creditor, the liquidator (if the company is in liquidation), or the Registrar of Companies for the appointment by the court of an administrator under section 239L of the Companies Act 1993 (inserted by section 6 of the Companies Amendment Act 2006) must be made by originating application under Part 19.
An application to the court by the administrator or other person entitled to apply to the court under Part 15A of the Companies Act 1993 must be made by originating application under Part 19.

If an application in relation to a company has been made to the court under subclause (1), any further application in relation to the voluntary administration of that company may be made by interlocutory application under subpart 2 of Part 7.
Subclause (1) is subject to subclause (2).
The proper registry of the court for the purpose of filing an originating application under rule 24.61 is—
the registry of the court in the town where, or the registry of the court in the town nearest to where, the company’s registered office is situated; or

if the company does not have a registered office, the registry of the court in the town where, or the registry of the court in the town nearest to where, the principal or last known place of business is or was situated.

If it appears to the court on application to it that the originating application has been filed in the wrong registry of the court, or that any other registry of the court would be more convenient to all parties affected, it may direct that the originating application and any documents filed in relation to that application be filed in, or transferred to, the proper registry or the other registry of the court.
This rule overrides rule 5.1.
In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires,—
Act means the Admiralty Act 1973
action means an action in personam or in rem, or both, in the admiralty jurisdiction of the court
foreign ship has the same meaning as it has in section 2(1) of the Maritime Transport Act 1994.
In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires, terms and expressions used and not defined in this Part but defined in the Act have the same meaning as in the Act.
Subpart 1 contains preliminary provisions and applies generally to actions.
Subpart 2 contains provisions about starting actions and applies generally to actions.
Subpart 3 contains provisions in addition to subpart 2 that apply to actions arising out of collisions between ships.
Subpart 4 contains provisions in addition to subpart 2 that apply to actions for the limitation of liability under Part 7 of the Maritime Transport Act 1994.
Subpart 5 applies to applications for judgment by default in actions.
Subpart 6 applies to the arrest, release, and sale of property in actions.
Subpart 7 contains miscellaneous provisions that apply generally to actions.

prov.heading: Application of other rules and practice of court

para.text: The other Parts of these rules and the general practice of the court apply when this Part applies unless modified by or inconsistent with the Act or this Part.

prov.heading: Parties can apply for directions if procedure not prescribed

para.text: A party or intending party who wishes to take a step in a proceeding for which a procedure is not prescribed by this Part or any other Part or by the general practice of the court may apply to the court or a Judge for directions.
The court or a Judge may give any directions concerning the steps to be taken by the party that the court or Judge thinks just.
A step in a proceeding is treated as having been properly taken if taken in accordance with the directions given under subclause (2).
An interlocutory application under this Part must be in form G 31 and an order made on that application must be in form G 34.

prov.heading: Action in personam or in rem, or both, started by notice of proceeding

para.text: Actions may be in personam or in rem, or both.
An action is started by a notice of proceeding—
issued from any registry of the court; and
endorsed, before being issued, with a concise statement of—
the nature of the claim; and
the relief or remedy required; and
the amount claimed (if any).
The concise statement referred to in subclause (2) is not a statement of claim within the meaning of these rules.
An action is treated as having started when a notice of proceeding complying with subclause (2) is filed.

prov.heading: Notice of proceeding for action in personam

para.text: An action in personam is started by a notice of proceeding in form AD 2.
The action must be headed as in form AD 1.
Rules 6.27 to 6.35 apply in relation to service out of the jurisdiction in an action in personam.

prov.heading: Notice of proceeding for action in rem

para.text: An action in rem is started by a notice of proceeding in form AD 4.
The action must be headed as in form AD 3.
No proceedings in rem concerning any claim against the Crown may be brought.

A notice of proceeding in rem may not be served out of the jurisdiction, but a notice of proceeding that is both in rem and in personam may be served out of the jurisdiction in so far as it is in personam.
Rules 6.27 to 6.35 apply to service out of the jurisdiction under subclause (4).

prov.heading: Notice of proceeding for action both in rem and in personam

para.text: An action that is both in rem and in personam is started by a notice of proceeding in form AD 5.
The action must be headed as in form AD 1.

prov.heading: How to serve notice of proceeding in action in rem on ship, cargo, or other property

para.text: To serve a notice of proceeding in an action in rem on a ship or on cargo or on other property on board a ship,—

attach a sealed copy of the notice to a place adjacent to the bridge or some conspicuous part of the ship, or adjacent to an entrance way to the superstructure or accommodation section of the ship; and
leave a copy of the notice with the person apparently in charge of the ship, if that person is available at the time of service.
To serve a notice of proceeding in an action in rem on cargo or on other property not on board a ship,—
attach a sealed copy of the notice to that cargo or other property; and
attach a copy of the notice to the place where the cargo or other property is located.
To serve a notice of proceeding in an action in rem on freight in the hands of an individual,—
show a sealed copy of the notice to that individual; and
leave a copy of the notice with that individual.
To serve a notice of proceeding in an action in rem on proceeds in court,—
show a sealed copy of the notice to the Registrar; and
leave a sealed copy of the notice with the Registrar.
To serve a notice of proceeding in an action in rem on inaccessible cargo or on other property,—
show a sealed copy of the notice to any person appearing to be in charge of that cargo or other property; and
leave a copy of the notice with that person.
Instead of serving a notice of proceeding in the appropriate manner set out in subclauses (1) to (5), service in an action in rem may be carried out in some other manner ordered by the court.

prov.heading: Other provisions about service in action in rem

para.text: A notice of proceeding in an action in rem may be served on a Sunday, Good Friday, or Christmas Day, or any public holiday, as well as on any other day.
The following provisions apply in an action in rem if a caveat against arrest is entered under rule 25.43:
the notice of proceeding must be served by or on behalf of the plaintiff or the plaintiff’s solicitor on any person at whose instance the caveat is entered:

a sealed copy of the notice must be delivered to the address for service given in the request for the caveat as soon as the plaintiff or the plaintiff’s solicitor becomes aware that the caveat is in force.
Service of a notice of proceeding or of a warrant of arrest is not required in an action in rem if the solicitor for a person interested in the defendant undertakes in writing to—
accept service; and
enter an appearance; and
give security or pay money into court instead of giving security.
An affidavit of service in an action in rem attaching as an exhibit a sealed copy of the notice of proceeding and stating the time, place, and method of service must be filed.
A defendant to an action must enter an appearance in person, or by a solicitor, by filing a memorandum in form AD 6 within the time and at the place directed in the notice of proceeding.
If 2 or more defendants to an action enter an appearance by the same solicitor at the same time, only 1 memorandum need be completed and filed.
A defendant to an action may enter a conditional appearance in the action, but a conditional appearance has effect as an unconditional appearance unless—
a Judge otherwise orders; or
the defendant applies to the court, within the period specified in rule 25.17, for an order under that rule and the court makes an order under that rule.
Every memorandum of appearance must contain an endorsement stating—
that the appearance is filed by the party appearing in person or by the party’s solicitor (as the case may be); and
if applicable, the solicitor’s name and address, and the name of the solicitor’s firm (if any); and
if applicable, the name and address of the solicitor acting as agent in the proceeding of the solicitor filing the appearance or of the agent’s firm (if any); and
an address for service.
A memorandum of appearance in an action in rem must also state—
the name and correct address of the party appearing and the capacity in which that party appears, whether as owner, part-owner, or otherwise; and
the port of registry or port to which the ship belongs.
A statement made under subclause (2) is prima facie evidence of the matters stated in it.
An appearance must be entered,—
for a notice of proceeding to be served within the jurisdiction, within 10 working days after the day of service:
for a notice of proceeding to be served outside the jurisdiction, within the period specified by an order granting leave to serve the notice outside the jurisdiction.
A party not entering an appearance within the specified period may, by consent of the other parties or by leave of the Judge, enter an appearance at any time on any terms that the Judge may order.
A party may not enter an appearance after judgment has been entered except with the leave of a Judge.
A memorandum of appearance may be filed by post and—
the appearance is treated as having been entered when the memorandum is actually received by the Registrar:
the duplicate copy to be returned to the party filing the memorandum may be returned by post.
When a memorandum of appearance is filed, the Registrar must—
enter an appearance in the Register of Admiralty Proceedings; and
return to the party filing the memorandum a duplicate copy showing the date of filing.
The party filing the memorandum of appearance must—
serve the duplicate copy on the plaintiff as soon as practicable; and
immediately serve registry copies on those other parties who have entered appearances.
A defendant to an action may apply to the court for an order for 1 or more of the following:
setting aside the notice of proceeding or service of the notice on the defendant:
declaring that the notice has not been duly served on the defendant:
discharging any order giving leave to serve the notice on the defendant out of the jurisdiction.
The application may be made—
at any time before entering an appearance in the action; or
if the defendant has entered a conditional appearance, within 5 working days after the day on which that conditional appearance is entered.
The court may make any order it thinks just.

A solicitor who, on behalf of any person, undertakes in writing to give security or to pay money into court instead of bail in an action in rem, and fails to fulfil that undertaking, is liable to punishment for contempt of court.

prov.heading: Substituted defendants, third parties, and interveners

para.text: Rules 25.12 to 25.18 apply, with the necessary modifications, to—
an added or substituted defendant:
a third or further party who is served with a third party notice:
an intervener who has obtained leave to intervene in an action.
Every action must be heard with pleadings, unless the court or a Judge otherwise orders under this rule or rule 25.23(5).
The plaintiff must file in court and serve a full and explicit statement of claim on each defendant, unless the court or a Judge gives leave to the contrary.

The steps required by subclause (2) must be taken either when the notice of proceeding is served on that defendant or at any time after service of the notice on that defendant, but in no case later than 10 working days after that defendant enters an appearance, unless the court or a Judge gives leave to the contrary or subclause (4) applies.

If preliminary acts are required under rule 25.23, the plaintiff must file in court and serve a statement of claim on each defendant within 10 working days after the latest date on which the preliminary act of any party to the action is filed, unless the court or a Judge orders the action to be tried without pleadings.

A defendant who enters an appearance in, and intends to defend, an action must file in court and serve a statement of defence on the plaintiff within 20 working days after the day on which a statement of claim is served on the defendant, unless the court or a Judge gives leave to the contrary.
A preliminary act is a document containing a statement of the following particulars:
the names of the ships that came into collision and their ports of registry:

particulars (referring to the period immediately before the collision) of the person in command, the persons on the bridge, and the persons keeping a lookout on the plaintiff’s ship (if the plaintiff is filing a preliminary act) and on the defendant’s ship (if the defendant is filing a preliminary act):
the date and time of the collision:
the place of the collision:
the direction and force of the wind:
the state of the weather including visibility:
the state, direction, and force of the tidal or other current:
the ship’s course and speed through the water when the other ship was first seen or immediately before any measures were taken in connection with its presence, whichever was the earlier:
the lights (if any) carried by the ship:
the distance and bearing of the other ship if and when its echo was first observed by radar:
the distance, bearing, and approximate heading of the other ship when first seen:
the other ship’s light or combination of lights (if any) when first seen:
the other lights or combination of lights (if any) of the other ship that were subsequently seen before the collision, and the time of the sighting:

the alterations (if any) made to the ship’s course and speed after the earlier of the 2 times referred to in paragraph (h) up to the time of the collision, and the times of those alterations, and the measures (if any), other than alterations of course or speed, taken to avoid the collision, and the times of those measures:
the parts of each ship that first came into contact and the approximate angle between the 2 ships at the moment of contact:
the sound signals or other signals (if any) given, and the times of those sound signals or other signals:
the sound signals or other signals (if any) heard or seen from the other ship, and the times of hearing or seeing those sound signals or other signals.

prov.heading: Preliminary acts to be filed in collision cases

para.text: In an action arising out of a collision between ships, unless the court otherwise orders,—
the plaintiff must file a preliminary act within 20 working days after the issue of the notice of proceeding:
the defendant must file a preliminary act within 20 working days after entering an appearance in the action and before any pleading is filed or served.
The Registrar must seal every preliminary act and file it in a closed envelope, and the envelope must be sealed with the official stamp of the court and show the date of filing.

The envelope must not be opened until the pleadings are closed and a consent signed by each of the parties to the opening of the preliminary acts is filed, unless the court or a Judge otherwise orders.

A party filing a preliminary act concerning a collision must, within 3 working days after it is filed, serve notice of the filing on every other party who has filed a preliminary act concerning the same collision.
If the court orders that the preliminary acts be opened, the court may also order that the action be tried without pleadings.
If the court or a Judge orders the action to be tried without pleadings, the court or a Judge may also order each party, within the period stated in the order,—
to file a statement of the grounds on which the party charges any other party with negligence in connection with the collision; and
to serve a copy of the statement on that other party.

prov.heading: Proceedings against party in default where other party fails to lodge preliminary act

para.text: A defendant in an action arising out of a collision between ships who has lodged a preliminary act within the specified period may apply to the court for an order to dismiss the action if the plaintiff fails to lodge a preliminary act within the specified period, and the court may by order dismiss the action or make any other order on any terms it thinks just.

The plaintiff to an action in personam arising out of a collision between ships who has lodged a preliminary act within the specified period may proceed to judgment under rule 25.29 if the defendant fails to lodge a preliminary act within the specified period, as if that failure were a failure to enter an appearance or to file a statement of defence within the periods specified by or under these rules for doing those things.

The plaintiff to an action in rem arising out of a collision between ships who has lodged a preliminary act within the specified period may apply to the court by motion for judgment against the defendant if the defendant fails to lodge a preliminary act within the specified period, and the plaintiff need not file or serve a statement of claim or an affidavit before the hearing of the motion.
On the hearing of the motion under subclause (3),—
the court may make any orders it thinks just; and

if the defendant does not appear on the hearing and the court considers that judgment should be given for the plaintiff provided the plaintiff proves the plaintiff’s case, the court must order that the plaintiff’s preliminary act be opened and require the plaintiff to satisfy the court that the plaintiff’s claim is well founded.
The plaintiff’s evidence may, unless the court otherwise orders, be given by affidavit.
On being satisfied that the plaintiff’s claim is well founded, the court may—
give judgment for the claim; and
at the same time,—
order that the property against which the action is brought be appraised and sold and the proceeds paid into court; or
make any other orders it thinks just.
The court may, on any terms it thinks just, set aside any judgment entered under this rule.

In this rule, references to the specified period are to be construed as references to the period within which, by virtue of rule 25.23(1) or of any order of the court or a Judge, the plaintiff or defendant, as the context of the reference requires, is required to lodge a preliminary act.

subpart.heading: Limitation of liability under Part 7 of Maritime Transport Act 1994

para.text: Proceedings for relief under Part 7 of the Maritime Transport Act 1994 must be in the form of an action in personam.

In the action the person seeking relief is the plaintiff and must be described in the notice of proceeding by name and not described merely as the owner of, or as bearing some other relation to, a particular ship or other property.
For the purposes of the proceedings,—
name includes a firm name or the name under which a person carries on business:

if any person with a claim against the plaintiff concerning the casualty to which the action relates has been described for the purposes of that claim merely as the owner of, or as bearing some other relation to, a ship or other property, that person may be described in that way as defendant to the notice of proceeding and, if described in that way, is to be treated for the purposes of this rule as having been named in the notice of proceeding by that person’s name.
At least 1 of the persons with claims against the plaintiff concerning the casualty to which the action relates must be described by name in the notice of proceeding as a defendant.
All persons with claims against the plaintiff concerning the casualty to which the action relates who are not named defendants may be described generally in the notice of proceeding as defendants.
The notice of proceeding must be served on 1 or more of the defendants who are named by their names, and need not be served on any other defendant.

prov.heading: Plaintiff must apply to court within 5 working days

para.text: The plaintiff in an action in personam for relief under Part 7 of the Maritime Transport Act 1994, without filing a statement of claim, must apply to the court by notice of motion for an order limiting the plaintiff’s liability or, in default of an order to that effect, for directions as to the further proceedings in the action, and the application must be made—
within 5 working days after the entry of appearance by 1 of the defendants named by their names in the notice of proceeding; or
if none of the defendants enters an appearance, within 5 working days after the period specified for appearing.
The application must be supported by an affidavit or affidavits proving—
the plaintiff’s case in the action; and
if none of the defendants named in the notice of proceeding by their names has entered an appearance, service of the notice of proceeding on at least 1 of the defendants so named; and

the names of all the persons (other than defendants to the action who are named in the notice of proceeding by their names) who, to the knowledge of the plaintiff, have claims against the plaintiff concerning the casualty to which the action relates; and
the address of each of those persons, if known to the plaintiff.
The motion and every affidavit in support of the motion must be served, at least 5 working days before the hearing of the application, on any defendant who has entered an appearance.

If, at the hearing of the application, it appears to the court that it is not disputed that the plaintiff has a right to limit the plaintiff’s liability, the court must make a decree limiting the plaintiff’s liability and fix the amount to which the liability is to be limited.

If, at the hearing of the application, it appears to the court that any defendant does not have sufficient information to enable the defendant to decide whether or not to dispute that the plaintiff has a right to limit the plaintiff’s liability, the court must—
give such directions as appear to be appropriate for enabling the defendant to obtain such information; and
adjourn the hearing.

If, on the hearing or resumed hearing of the application, the court does not make a decree limiting the plaintiff’s liability, the court must give such directions as to the further proceedings in the action as appear to be appropriate.

A defendant who, after directions have been given under subclause (6), ceases to dispute the plaintiff’s right to limit the plaintiff’s liability must immediately file a notice to that effect in the registry of the court and serve a copy on the plaintiff and on every other defendant who has entered an appearance.

If every defendant who disputes the plaintiff’s right to limit the plaintiff’s liability serves a notice on the plaintiff under subclause (7), the plaintiff may apply to the court for an order limiting the plaintiff’s liability, and subclauses (3) and (4) apply to the application with the necessary modifications.

This rule applies if the only defendants in an action in personam for relief under Part 7 of the Maritime Transport Act 1994 are those named in the summons by their names and all those defendants have been served.
An order limiting the plaintiff’s liability—
need not be advertised; but
if not advertised, operates only to protect the plaintiff against claims by the named defendants or persons claiming through or under those persons.
To protect the plaintiff’s liability against claims by other persons as well as the defendants and persons referred to in subclause (2)﻿(b), an order limiting the plaintiff’s liability must—
be advertised by the plaintiff in the manner provided, and within the period specified, in the order; and

specify a period within which persons with claims against the plaintiff concerning the casualty to which the action relates may enter an appearance in the action (if they have not already done so) and file their claims, and, in cases to which subclause (5) applies, file a motion, if they think fit, to set the order aside.

The period to be allowed under subclause (3)﻿(b), unless the court otherwise orders, must be not less than 2 months from the latest date allowed for the appearance of the advertisement and, after the expiration of the period so allowed, leave of the court is required to enter an appearance, file a claim, or to make an application to set aside the order.
If an order limiting the plaintiff’s liability specifies a period in accordance with subclause (3),—

a person with a claim against the plaintiff concerning the casualty to which the action relates who is not named in the notice of proceeding as a defendant to the action may, within the specified period after entering an appearance, apply on notice for the order to be set aside:

a person with a claim against the plaintiff concerning the casualty to which the action relates who is named but was not served with the notice of proceeding and has not entered an appearance may, within the specified period after entering an appearance, apply on notice for the order to be set aside.

An application under subclause (4) must be supported by an affidavit or affidavits showing that the defendant in question makes a claim in good faith against the plaintiff concerning the casualty in question and that the defendant has sufficient prima facie grounds for the contention that the plaintiff is not entitled to the relief given to the plaintiff by the order.

An application under subclause (4) and every affidavit in support of the application must be served, at least 5 working days before the hearing of the motion, on the plaintiff and on any defendant who has entered an appearance.

If satisfied that the defendant concerned is making a claim in good faith against the plaintiff, and that it is reasonably arguable that the plaintiff is not entitled to the relief given to the plaintiff by the order, the court must set the order aside and give any directions as to the further proceedings in the action that appear appropriate.

Any order limiting the plaintiff’s liability in an action in personam for relief under Part 7 of the Maritime Transport Act 1994 may make any provision authorised by section 89 of the Maritime Transport Act 1994.

prov.heading: Who may seek judgment by default in action in personam

para.text: Rules 15.4 to 15.14 apply to actions in personam.

A plaintiff to an action in personam is entitled to proceed to judgment if the defendant fails, within the period specified by or under this Part, either to enter an appearance or to file a statement of defence.
Judgment under this rule must not exceed the amount endorsed on the notice of proceeding or claimed in the statement of claim concerning the demand for costs.

prov.heading: Default in filing and service of statement of claim

para.text: This rule applies if the plaintiff to an action in personam or in rem is required by these rules to file in court a statement of claim and to serve it on a defendant, but the plaintiff fails to do either of those things.
The defendant may, after the expiration of the period specified by or under these rules for filing the statement of claim, apply to the court for an order to dismiss the action.
The court may by order dismiss the action or make any other order on any terms it thinks just.
The court may, on any terms it thinks just, set aside or vary any default judgment entered under this rule.
Rule 4.17 applies if a third party fails to enter an appearance, as if the failure to enter an appearance were a failure to file a statement of defence.

prov.heading: Application for judgment by default in action in rem

para.text: An application for judgment by default in an action in rem must be made by motion.
In default actions in rem, evidence may, unless the court otherwise orders, be given by affidavit.
The plaintiff may, on filing an affidavit verifying the facts on which the action is based, apply to the court for judgment by default if—
a notice of proceeding is served under rule 25.11(2) on a party at whose instance a caveat against arrest has been issued; and

the sum claimed in the action begun by the notice of proceeding does not exceed the amount specified in the undertaking given by that party or that party’s solicitor to procure the entry of that caveat; and
that party or that party’s solicitor does not, within 10 working days after service of the notice of proceeding, fulfil that undertaking.
A plaintiff to an action in rem may apply to the court for judgment by default if—
the defendant to the action fails to enter an appearance within the period specified for appearing; and
not less than 10 working days has passed since the notice of proceeding was served; and

the plaintiff has filed an affidavit proving due service of the notice of proceeding, a statement of claim (where one has not already been filed), and an affidavit verifying the facts on which the action is based.
A plaintiff to an action in rem may apply to the court for judgment by default if—
the defendant to the action fails to file and serve a statement of defence on the plaintiff within the period specified by or under these rules for filing and service of the defence; and
the plaintiff has filed—
an affidavit stating that no defence was served on the plaintiff by that defendant during the period referred to in paragraph (a); and
an affidavit verifying the facts on which the action is based.
A party making a counterclaim in an action in rem may apply to the court for judgment by default if—

the defendant to the counterclaim fails to file and serve a defence to the counterclaim on the party making the counterclaim within the period specified by or under these rules for the filing and service of the defence to a counterclaim; and
the party making the counterclaim has filed—
an affidavit stating that no defence to the counterclaim has been served on that party by the defendant during that period; and
an affidavit verifying the facts on which the counterclaim is based.

prov.heading: Judgment by default in action in rem

para.text: On being satisfied at the hearing that the applicant’s claim in an action in rem is well founded, the court may—
give judgment for the claim; and
at the same time,—
order the property against which the action, or, as the case may be, the counterclaim is brought to be appraised and sold and the proceeds to be paid into court; or
make any other orders it thinks just.
Judgment given under subclause (1) may be enforced by—
arrest of the property against which the action was brought:
committal of the party at whose instance the caveat against that property was entered.
The court may, on any terms it thinks just, set aside or vary any judgment by default entered in an action in rem.

subpart.heading: Arrest, release, and sale of property

prov.heading: Application for warrant of arrest of property

para.text: After the issue of a notice of proceeding or counterclaim in rem, the plaintiff or the defendant to the notice or counterclaim may, by an application in form AD 7, apply for the issue of a warrant of arrest of the property against which the action or counterclaim is brought.
However, if 2 or more ships owned by the same person are named as defendant in an action arising from a cause of action concerning 1 ship only,—
a warrant of arrest may be issued against 1 ship only; and
the plaintiff must name that ship in the application for the warrant of arrest.
The applicant for the issue of a warrant of arrest must cause a search to be made to determine whether any caveat against the issue of the warrant is in force.
In support of the application for a warrant of arrest, the applicant must file—
an affidavit stating—
the name and description of the party at whose instance the warrant is to be issued; and
the nature of the claim; and
the name or nature of the property to be arrested; and
the extent to which the claim has been satisfied, the amount claimed paid into court, or security for payment of the claim given to the Registrar; and

whether any caveat against the issue of a warrant of arrest has been filed and, if so, whether a copy of the notice of proceeding or a notice requiring payment or security has been served on the caveator; and
any other relevant information known to the applicant at the time the application is made; and

an indemnity to the Registrar in form AD 8 and security to the satisfaction of the Registrar for the fees, expenses, and harbour dues (if any) of the Registrar and of the Registrar’s appointed officers and agents.
The Registrar may require additional security to cover fees, expenses, and harbour dues (if any) referred to in rule 25.34(4)﻿(b).

The Registrar must, before issuing the warrant of arrest, ascertain whether a caveat against the issue of a warrant of arrest has been entered, but, under rule 25.43(2), the entry of a caveat against arrest does not prevent the issue of a warrant of arrest.
On being satisfied that the relevant requirements of rule 25.34 and this rule have been complied with, the Registrar must—
complete the certificate on the application for a warrant of arrest; and
issue a warrant of arrest in form AD 9.
Despite subclause (2), a Registrar may, in the case of any emergency or special circumstances, issue a warrant of arrest immediately if the Registrar—
is satisfied that a notice of proceeding has been issued and that there is either an emergency or special circumstances which justify the immediate issue of a warrant of arrest; and
is given an indemnity that the Registrar requires against any claim arising out of the issue of a warrant of arrest.
The Registrar may, instead of completing the certificate on the application for warrant of arrest, endorse the application to the effect that the warrant is issued under subclause (4).

history.history-note: Rule 25.35(3): amended, on 1 January 2011, by rule 11 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2010 (SR 2010/394).

para.text: The warrant must be served by—
the Registrar; or
a person lawfully authorised (whether generally or specially for the purpose) to act as the Registrar.

The Registrar or other authorised person must serve the warrant in the manner specified by these rules for the service of a notice of proceeding in an action in rem, and the property is to be treated as having been arrested when the warrant has been served by the Registrar or other authorised person in that manner.
The warrant may be served on a Sunday, Good Friday, or Christmas Day, or any public holiday, as well as on any other day.
A Registrar may, by fax or other means of communication,—
send notice to the Registrar’s appointed officer or agent, or to any other Registrar, of the issue of a warrant of arrest of any ship:
give instructions for the execution of the warrant.
A warrant of arrest is valid for 6 months beginning on the day of issue unless sooner withdrawn, and successive warrants may be issued.
The Registrar must give notice of the arrest of property by serving on any person or by affixing on a conspicuous part of the property a notice in form AD 10.
Service may be made by the Registrar’s duly appointed officer or agent.
Rules 25.34(4)﻿(b) and 25.35(4)﻿(b) do not require the Crown to give any indemnity or security.

prov.heading: Contempt to move ship under arrest

para.text: This rule applies to—
the master of a ship having notice of the issue of a warrant of arrest of the ship:
any other person having notice of the arrest of the ship.
It is contempt of court for the master or other person to move the ship from where it is lying without the consent of the Registrar.

prov.heading: Application for directions concerning property under arrest

para.text: The Registrar or any party to an action in rem may apply to the court for directions concerning any property under arrest (including directions for the removal of the property).
The person applying must give notice of the application to all parties to the action unless the court otherwise orders.

prov.heading: Request for caveat against arrest of property

para.text: A person may request a caveat against the arrest of any property by filing a request in form AD 11 signed by the person or the person’s solicitor undertaking—
to enter an appearance in any action that may be started against the property described in the request; and

within 3 working days after receiving notice that such an action has been started, to give security to the satisfaction of the Registrar in the sum specified in the request or to pay that sum into court.

If the amount claimed in the action does not exceed the amount specified in the undertaking, the caveator must pay into court or give security for the amount claimed within 3 working days after the day of service of the notice of proceeding or counterclaim.

If the caveator fails to pay into court or give security in accordance with this rule, and the party seeking the issue of a warrant of arrest suffers any loss as a result, the court may order the caveator to pay to that party damages for that loss unless the caveator shows good and sufficient reason for that failure.
Immediately on the filing of a request under rule 25.42, the Registrar must enter a caveat in the Register of Admiralty Proceedings.

Neither this Part nor the entry of a caveat under this rule prevents a party from taking out a warrant for the arrest of property, but if a caveat is entered under this rule against the arrest of property and a party has that property arrested, that party is liable for costs and damages unless the party shows good and sufficient reason for the arrest.
A caveat under this rule is valid for 6 months commencing on the day after the date on which it is entered unless sooner withdrawn, and successive caveats may be entered.

A caveat under this rule may be withdrawn at any time by the filing of a notice of withdrawal signed by the caveator or the caveator’s solicitor, but the withdrawal does not affect any rights or obligations that may have accrued at the date of the withdrawal.
The court may, on its own initiative or on application, set aside a caveat entered under this rule.

A party interested in any property arrested under a warrant of arrest may request a Registrar to issue an instrument of release (a release) in form AD 12 for the release of the property unless the property is sold under an order of the court.
The release must be issued out of the registry where the action in which the warrant was issued is proceeding.
The Registrar must, before issuing the release, cause a search to be made to ascertain whether a caveat against release of the property in question is in force.
Before a release is issued, the party entitled to its issue must,—
if a caveat against release of the property in question is in force, give notice to the party at whose instance it was entered or that party’s solicitor requiring that the caveat be withdrawn; and
file a request for the issue of a release.

Before property under arrest is released in compliance with a release issued under this rule, the party at whose instance it was issued must, in accordance with the directions of the Registrar, either pay the costs, charges, and expenses due in connection with the care and custody of the property while under arrest or give a written undertaking to pay those costs, charges, and expenses.
The court, on the application of any party who objects to directions given to that party by the Registrar under subclause (5), may vary or revoke the directions.
A Registrar may issue a release either—
on the order of the court at the request of a party interested in the property under arrest; or
by consent of all the other parties to the action in which the warrant of arrest was issued, unless release on this basis is prevented by a court order.
A Registrar may issue a release under subclause (1) either—
on payment into court of the amount claimed in the notice of proceeding together with the costs of issue and execution of the warrant of arrest; or
on security (including a bail bond in form AD 13) for those amounts having been given to the satisfaction of the Registrar.
A release must not be issued for property under subclause (1) if a caveat against release of that property is in force, unless the court otherwise orders.
A release must be issued for property if,—
before an appearance is entered in the action concerned, a party at whose instance the property was arrested files a notice withdrawing the warrant of arrest; and
rule 25.44(4) has been complied with (if applicable) and the release is not prevented by subclause (3).

A person may prevent the release of property under arrest in an action in rem or the payment out of court of any money in court representing the proceeds of sale of that property, or both that release and that payment, by filing a request for a caveat in form AD 14.
On the filing of the request, the Registrar must enter in the Register of Admiralty Proceedings a caveat against—
the issue of a release for the property; or
the payment out of court of the money in court; or
both.
The caveator must serve a copy of the caveat on every party to the action.

A party who delays the release of property by entry of a caveat is liable in damages to any person having an interest in the property, unless that party shows to the satisfaction of the court good and sufficient reason for having the caveat entered.
A caveat under this rule is valid for 6 months commencing on the day after the date of entering, unless sooner withdrawn, but successive caveats may be entered.
A caveat under this rule may be withdrawn by filing a notice of withdrawal signed by the caveator or the caveator’s solicitor.
The court may, on its own initiative or on application, set aside a caveat issued under this rule.

prov.heading: Discharge of cargo under arrest from ships not under arrest and of cargo not under arrest

para.text: If a ship is not under arrest but cargo on board the ship is, persons interested in the ship who wish to discharge the cargo under arrest may, without intervening in the action, request the Registrar to take the appropriate steps in accordance with this rule.
The Registrar must apply to the court under rule 25.41 for the appropriate order if—
the Registrar considers the request reasonable; and

the applicant gives the Registrar a satisfactory undertaking in writing to pay on demand the fees and expenses incurred by the Registrar, and any of the Registrar’s appointed officers or agents, in taking the desired steps.

If the interested persons are unable or unwilling to arrange for an undertaking under subclause (2)﻿(b) to be given, they may intervene in the action in which the cargo is under arrest and apply for an order for discharge of the cargo and for directions as to the fees and expenses incurred by the Registrar, and any of the Registrar’s appointed officers or agents, in discharging and storing the cargo under the order.
If a ship is under arrest but cargo on board the ship is not, persons interested in the cargo who wish to secure its discharge may follow one or other of the procedures specified in this rule.
The amount and form of any security required under this Part may be determined by the court or a Judge on an application by any party.
If security is being given by a person not ordinarily resident within the jurisdiction, that person must—
submit to the jurisdiction of the court for all purposes relating to the security and its enforcement, unless otherwise ordered by the court; and
give an address for service within the jurisdiction of the court.
No money paid into court in any action may be paid out of court except under subclause (2) or by order of the court or a Judge.
With the written consent of all parties to the action and of any caveator and of any intervener under rule 25.50, the Registrar may authorise money to be paid out of court.

If property against which an action in rem is brought is under arrest or money representing the proceeds of sale of that property is in court, a person who has an interest in that property or money but who is not a defendant to the action may intervene in the action.
The intervener must file papers appropriate to the proceeding and serve those papers on every other party.
A party may request a commission for the appraisement and sale of any property under arrest of the court by filing a request in form AD 15.
The court may, either before or after final judgment, order that any property described in the request—
be appraised; or
be sold with or without appraisement, and either by public auction or by private contract.
If the property is deteriorating in value, the court may order that it be sold immediately.
If the property sold is of small value, the court may, if it thinks just, order that it be sold without a commission of sale being issued.
The commission for the appraisement must be in form AD 16 and must, unless the court otherwise orders, be executed by the Registrar or the Registrar’s duly appointed officer or agent.

A commission for appraisement and sale may not be executed until an undertaking in writing, satisfactory to the Registrar, to pay the Registrar’s fees and expenses on demand has been lodged in the Registrar’s registry.

The Registrar must pay into court the gross proceeds of the sale of any property sold by the Registrar under a commission for sale, and must bring into court the account relating to the sale (with vouchers in support).

prov.heading: Determination of priority of claims where court orders sale of ship

para.text: In making an order for the sale of a ship in an action in rem, the court may further order—

that the order of priority of the claims against the proceeds of sale of the ship not be determined until after the expiration of 65 working days, or of any other period specified by the court, beginning with the day on which the proceeds of sale are paid into court:

that any party to the action or to any other action in rem against the ship or the proceeds of sale of the ship may apply to the court in the action to which that party is a party to extend the period specified in the order:

that, within 5 working days after the date of payment into court of the proceeds of sale, the Registrar must send a notice in form AD 17 for publication in the Gazette and such newspaper (if any) as the court may direct.

A party who obtains judgment against the ship or the proceeds of sale of the ship may, on obtaining judgment, apply to the court by motion for an order determining the order of priority of the claims against the proceeds of sale of the ship.

However, if the order for sale contains a further order referred to in subclause (1), an application for an order determining priorities may be made only after the expiration of the period that applies under paragraph (a) or (b) of that subclause.
An application to the court to extend the period referred to in subclause (1)﻿(a) must be served on each party who has begun an action in rem against the ship or the proceeds of sale of the ship.
The Registrar must lodge in the registry a copy of each newspaper in which the notice referred to in subclause (1)﻿(c) appeared.
The expenses incurred by the Registrar in complying with an order of the court under this rule must be included in the Registrar’s expenses relating to the sale of the ship.

The court may, on the application of any party, make an order for the inspection by a court expert, or by any party or witness, of any ship or other property, whether real or personal, if the inspection is necessary or desirable for the purpose of obtaining full information or evidence in connection with any issue in the action.
Subclause (1) does not limit the court’s powers under any other provision of these rules.

Any agreement in writing between the parties to a cause or matter that is dated and signed by the parties or their solicitors may be filed if the Registrar thinks it is reasonable to file the agreement.
The agreement becomes an order of the court when it is filed.
The Registrar may apply to the court for orders to assist the Registrar in the performance or exercise of any function, duty, right, or power conferred or imposed on the Registrar by this Part.
The court may make any orders it thinks just concerning the performance or exercise of that function, duty, right, or power.

prov.heading: Parties may seek review of Registrar’s decision

para.text: Any party to a proceeding who is affected by a decision of the Registrar under this Part may apply, by interlocutory application, to review that decision.
The court may make any orders it thinks just.
In this Part,—
Act means the Arbitration Act 1996
arbitral tribunal has the same meaning as in section 2(1) of the Act
Judge includes Associate Judge
Schedule 1 means Schedule 1 of the Act
Schedule 2 means Schedule 2 of the Act.
This Part applies to—
an appeal under clause 5(1)﻿(a) or (b) of Schedule 2:
an application for leave to appeal under clause 5(1)﻿(c) of Schedule 2:
an application for entry of an award as a judgment under article 35 of Schedule 1.

subpart.heading: Appeals under clause 5(1)﻿(a) or (b) of Schedule 2

para.text: The plaintiff must commence an appeal to which clause 5(1)﻿(a) or (b) of Schedule 2 applies by filing an originating application in the proper registry determined under rule 5.1.
The originating application—
must be in form Arb 1; and
must not name the arbitral tribunal as a defendant.
Rule 5.44 applies to the originating application.

The application must attach the award or arbitral tribunal’s decision to which the appeal relates, but if it is not available at the date of the application it must be filed by the applicant immediately it becomes available.
This rule has effect despite rule 5.25 or Part 18.

prov.heading: Affidavit to be filed in support

para.text: At the same time as the originating application is filed, the plaintiff must file an affidavit proving that the appeal falls within clause 5(1)﻿(a) or (b) of Schedule 2, as the case may be.
The plaintiff must serve copies of the originating application and the affidavit on the defendant either before or immediately after filing.
The grounds of the appeal may be subsequently amended by leave of the court.
A defendant intending to oppose the originating application must—
file a notice of opposition; and
serve it on the plaintiff and all other parties.
The notice of opposition—
must be filed within 10 working days after service of the originating application; and
must state the defendant’s intention to oppose the application and the grounds of opposition, including—
a denial of any fact stated in the originating application that is not admitted; and
a statement of any fact or matter, not mentioned in the originating application, on which the defendant relies; and
must contain a reference to any enactment, or rule, or principle of law on which the defendant relies; and
must be in form G 33, with any necessary modifications.
A defendant wishing to cross-appeal at the hearing of the originating application in the circumstances set out in subclause (2) must—
file a notice of cross-appeal; and
serve it on the plaintiff and all other parties.
The circumstances are that—
the defendant intends to contend at the hearing that another question of law arises out of the award; and
the other question is the reason for the cross-appeal; and
clause 5(1)﻿(a) or (b) of Schedule 2 applies with respect to the other question.
The notice of cross-appeal—
must be filed within 10 working days after service of the plaintiff’s originating application; and
must be in form Arb 1, with any necessary modifications.
This Part applies to cross-appeals with all necessary modifications.
This rule and rule 26.10 apply if the court gives a direction under rule 7.5(7)﻿(d)﻿(i) at a case management conference or at any other time.
The record of the arbitration comprises any—
application, documents, written submissions, statements, reports, and other papers lodged with the arbitral tribunal; and
transcript of evidence; and
exhibits.
Despite subclause (2), a part of the record must be omitted from the record filed if the parties agree that it is unnecessary for the hearing of the appeal.
The cost of preparing the record—
must be met by the plaintiff; and
is a disbursement in the proceeding.
The plaintiff must serve a properly indexed copy of the record of the arbitration on the defendant within 20 working days of the direction.
Within 5 working days after service of the proposed record and index, the defendant must,—
if agreeing to the record and index, signify agreement by signing the index; or
advise the plaintiff of changes sought to the proposed record or index.
After the defendant has taken the steps in subclause (2), the plaintiff must file, without delay,—
a properly indexed copy of the record; and
a memorandum setting out changes sought by the defendant and the plaintiff’s reasons for not agreeing to them, if applicable; and
any further documents that the defendant contends form part of the record.
The court may direct the plaintiff to file a further copy of the record if an appeal is to be heard by more than 1 Judge.
This rule and rule 26.12 apply if the court gives a direction under rule 7.5(7)﻿(d)﻿(ii) at a case management conference or at any other time.
The court may order that a transcript be made of any recorded evidence given in the arbitration—
if it is satisfied that the transcript is required to properly determine the appeal; and
subject to any conditions that the court thinks just.
The cost of preparing a transcript is a disbursement in the proceeding.
The plaintiff must serve the proposed transcript on the defendant within 20 working days of the direction.
Within 5 working days after service of the proposed transcript, the defendant must—
agree to the transcript, and signify agreement by appropriately certifying the transcript; or
advise the plaintiff of—
changes sought; and
additional evidence to be transcribed.
After the defendant has taken the steps in subclause (2), the plaintiff must file, without delay,—
the transcript; and
a memorandum setting out changes sought by the defendant and the plaintiff’s reasons for not agreeing to them, if applicable.
The defendant may file a transcript of evidence if—
the defendant sought to have additional evidence transcribed; and
the plaintiff disputed—
the relevance of the evidence; or
the necessity of transcribing it for the hearing.
The court may direct a party submitting a transcript to file a further copy of it if an appeal is to be heard by more than 1 Judge.
Appeals are by way of rehearing.
In an appeal, the court has all the powers and discretions of an arbitral tribunal—
to hold the hearing or any part of it in private; and
to make orders prohibiting the publication of any report or description of the proceedings or any part of them.

prov.heading: Leave to appeal to Court of Appeal

para.text: An application to the High Court under clause 5(5) of Schedule 2 for leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal must be filed within 20 working days of the High Court’s determining the appeal under clause 5(4) of Schedule 2.

subpart.heading: Leave to appeal under clause 5(1)﻿(c) of Schedule 2

para.text: The plaintiff must commence a proceeding to which clause 5(1)﻿(c) of Schedule 2 applies by filing an originating application in the proper registry determined under rule 5.1.
The originating application—
must be in form Arb 2; and
must not name the arbitral tribunal as a defendant.
In relation to the originating application, the following apply:
rule 5.44; and
rules 26.4 to 26.7, with all necessary modifications.
This rule has effect despite rule 5.25 or Part 18.
The plaintiff must file the following within 10 working days of the time specified in subclause (2):
submissions as to why leave should be granted:
copies of any authorities relied on.
The time is whichever of the following applies:
the date on which the plaintiff is served with a notice of opposition:
the date by which the defendant must file a notice of opposition if the defendant wishes to oppose the application.
Copies of material filed must be served immediately on any defendant who has filed and served a notice of opposition.
At the hearing, unless otherwise directed by the Judge,—
the plaintiff or his or her counsel is restricted to 30 minutes; and
the defendant or his or her counsel is restricted to 30 minutes; and
the plaintiff or his or her counsel is restricted to 10 minutes by way of reply.
The court need not give reasons for granting leave unless it thinks reasons are required in the circumstances.
The court must give reasons if it refuses to grant leave.

prov.heading: Applying to Court of Appeal for leave to appeal

para.text: An application to the court under clause 5(5) of Schedule 2 for leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal from a refusal to grant leave to appeal must be filed within 20 working days of the refusal.

subpart.heading: Entry of award as judgment under article 35 of Schedule 1

prov.heading: Entry of judgment if all parties agree

para.text: All parties to an award who agree that it may be entered as a judgment may apply to a Registrar by letter signed by all parties or their solicitor or counsel requesting the entry of the award as a judgment.
The Registrar must enter the award as a judgment as soon as practicable—
if he or she is satisfied that all parties have agreed; and
if he or she is satisfied with respect to the matters set out in article 35(2) of Schedule 1.

prov.heading: Entry of judgment in other cases

para.text: If rule 26.20 does not apply, a party to an award who wishes to enforce it may—
enforce it by action; or
apply to the court for entry of the award as a judgment.
A party electing the method set out in subclause (1)﻿(a) must commence a proceeding under Part 5.
A party electing the method set out in subclause (1)﻿(b) must follow the procedure set out in rules 26.22 to 26.27.

prov.heading: Application for entry of award as judgment

para.text: The party to the award must file an originating application in the proper registry, determined under rule 5.1.
The originating application—
must be in form Arb 3; and
must not name the arbitral tribunal as a defendant.
Rule 5.44 applies to the originating application.
This rule has effect despite anything in rule 5.25 or Part 18.

prov.heading: Affidavit to be filed in support

para.text: At the same time as the originating application is filed, the plaintiff must file an affidavit proving the matters set out in article 35(2) of Schedule 1.
The plaintiff must serve copies of both the originating application and the affidavit on the defendant either before or immediately after filing.
Subclause (1) does not apply if the plaintiff obtains an order under rule 26.25.

prov.heading: Entry as judgment without notice in exceptional circumstances

para.text: In exceptional circumstances, the plaintiff may, on or after the filing of the originating application, file an application without notice for an order that the award be entered as a judgment.
The application must be supported by an affidavit that sets out the exceptional circumstances that justify the order sought.
The court may determine the application without notice and make the order sought if satisfied that the order is required in the interests of justice.
If the court makes the order sought, the court may also direct that the award not be enforced before it has been served on the defendant and a period specified by the court has expired after service.

prov.heading: Entry as judgment if defendant takes no steps

para.text: The Registrar must enter the award as a judgment as soon as practicable if—
the defendant takes no steps within the time specified in subclause (2); and
the plaintiff makes an application for the entry.
The time is whichever of the following applies:
10 working days after the plaintiff’s application is served on the defendant; or
a period fixed by the court of less than 10 working days after the order fixing that period is served on the defendant.
An application to the Registrar under subclause (1)﻿(b)—
is made by letter signed by the plaintiff or his or her solicitor or counsel requesting the entry of the award as a judgment; and
need not be served on the defendant.
An application for an order under subclause (2)﻿(b) may be made without notice.
An order under subclause (2)﻿(b) does not take effect unless it is served on the defendant together with the documents referred to in rule 26.24(1).

Subclause (5) applies even if the originating application to which the order relates has already been served on the defendant, and in that case the previous service of the application ceases to have effect when the order is made.
This rule applies if a defendant wishes to oppose the originating application.
The plaintiff’s application is stayed pending the determination of an application under this rule.
The defendant must file and serve an application seeking an order for refusal of recognition and enforcement in terms of article 36 of Schedule 1.
The application referred to in subclause (3) must be—
filed and served within the applicable period specified in rule 26.26(2); and
treated as if it were an originating application under Part 19; and
disposed of in accordance with Part 19; and
determined at the same time as the plaintiff’s application to enforce the award by entry as a judgment.

To avoid doubt, an application under this rule is concerned with the recognition or enforcement of an award and not with any question of law arising out of the award that may be determined by the court or the Court of Appeal under clause 5 of Schedule 2 of the Act.

history.history-note: Rule 26.27(5): inserted, on 3 June 2014, by rule 14 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/127).

prov.heading: Wills and intestacies to which this Part applies

para.text: The rules in this Part apply to—
the wills (whenever made) of persons who die on or after 1 November 2007; and
grants of administration in respect of persons who die intestate on or after the date when these rules come into force.
The rules in this Part, except rule 27.14, do not apply to the wills of persons who died before 1 November 2007.

The High Court Rules set out in Schedule 2 of the Judicature Act 1908 before their amendment by the High Court Amendment (Wills Act 2007) Rules 2007, except for the amendment in rule 27.14, apply to the wills of persons who died before 1 November 2007.

history.history-note: Rule 27.1(1)﻿(a): amended, on 4 February 2013, by rule 25 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

para.text: For the purposes of this Part,—
administration—
means probate of a deceased’s will; and
includes letters of administration of a deceased’s estate, granted with or without a will annexed, for general, special, or limited purposes; and
for Public Trust or the Māori Trustee or a trustee company as defined in the Trustee Companies Act 1967, includes—
an order to administer; and
an election to administer
administrator—
means a person to whom administration is granted; and
includes Public Trust or the Māori Trustee or a trustee company as defined in the Trustee Companies Act 1967 treated as an executor or administrator because it has filed an election to administer
executed, for a will, means signed and witnessed in accordance with the requirements of section 11(3) and (4) of the Wills Act 2007
grant means a grant of administration
will has the same meaning as in section 8 of the Wills Act 2007.

history.history-note: Rule 27.2 executed: replaced, on 4 February 2013, by rule 26 of the High Court Amendment Rules (No 2) 2012 (SR 2012/409).

para.text: An application for a grant is made by—
an application without notice under rule 27.4; or
an application in solemn form under rule 27.6.
This rule applies to an application without notice.
Rule 5.36 does not apply to the application.
The application must be made in form PR 1AA.

If the applicant knew the deceased or knows about the deceased’s death personally, the applicant must file an affidavit in whichever is appropriate of forms PR 1 to PR 6 to prove the deceased’s death.
If the applicant did not know the deceased and does not know about the deceased’s death personally,—
paragraphs 1 and 2 of forms PR 1 to PR 6 must be omitted; and
another person must swear an affidavit proving the deceased’s death, in the form of paragraphs 1 and 2 of form PR 1.

If the application is for a grant of probate or a grant of letters of administration with the will annexed, the applicant must file an affidavit in form PR 1 or PR 2 to prove the validity of the will that the application is about.
A form presented for filing under this rule is not invalid just because it contains minor differences from a prescribed form as long as the form still has the same effect and is not misleading.

history.history-note: Rule 27.4(3): replaced, on 1 September 2017, by rule 24(1) of the High Court Rules 2016 Amendment Rules (No 2) 2017 (LI 2017/191).
Rule 27.4(4): revoked, on 1 September 2017, by rule 24(2) of the High Court Rules 2016 Amendment Rules (No 2) 2017 (LI 2017/191).
Rule 27.4(8): revoked, on 1 September 2017, by rule 24(2) of the High Court Rules 2016 Amendment Rules (No 2) 2017 (LI 2017/191).

prov.heading: Restrictions if possibly invalid will exists

para.text: This rule applies if the applicant—
knows of a will later than the will that the application is about; and
has reason to believe that the later will is invalid.
This rule also applies if the applicant—
seeks a grant because the deceased was intestate; and
knows of a will; and
has reason to believe that the will is invalid.
The applicant may make an application under rule 27.4 containing proof that—
the applicant has given the executor named in the will written or electronic notice of the applicant’s intention to apply; and
the executor has not applied for a grant within 1 month after service of the notice; and
a caveat has not been lodged against a grant within 1 month after service of the notice.
The court—
may direct the applicant to apply for an order under section 53 of the Administration Act 1969; and
must defer dealing with the application under rule 27.4 until the application under section 53 has been determined.
This rule applies to an application in solemn form.
An application is made in solemn form if—
the applicant chooses to apply in that way; or
the applicant is ordered to apply in that way.
Part 5 applies to the application.
The procedure for dealing with the application is the same as for an ordinary proceeding, subject to the rules in this Part.
The applicant may apply to the court for directions as to the persons to be named as respondents to an application under rule 27.6.
If the applicant does not apply, or if the court does not give directions, the applicant must name as respondents—
the person who may be entitled to a grant if the applicant does not obtain the grant; and
all persons who have lodged caveats under rule 27.11.
A person interested in the result of an application under rule 27.6 may apply to the court to be added as a party.
If the court is satisfied that the interests of the person are not already adequately represented, it may—
order that the person be added; and
impose conditions on the order, if necessary; and
give directions as to the part that the person is to take in the hearing of the application.
This rule applies if an application under rule 27.6 is the subject of a compromise, whether or not a statement of defence has been filed.
The court may direct—
that the application is to be treated as an application under rule 27.4; and
that evidence on the application may be given by affidavit.
This rule applies to an application under rule 27.6 in which a pleading states that the will that the application relates to is invalid.
This rule also applies to an application under rule 27.6 in which a pleading states that a will that is the subject of a grant obtained by way of an application without notice is invalid.
The pleading must state the substance of the case against validity.
If the allegation is that the will’s execution was not valid, the pleading must state the facts on which the allegation is based.
If the allegation is that the will-maker did not have testamentary capacity when the will was executed, the pleading must state whether the incapacity lay in any or all of the following:
the will-maker’s lack of ability to comprehend or recollect the extent of his or her estate; or
the will-maker’s lack of ability to comprehend or recollect the claims of persons excluded from participating in his or her estate; or
the will-maker’s insane delusions about the persons who have claims on his or her estate; or
some other specified incapacity.

An application without notice under rule 27.4 and all documents relating to that application must be filed in the registry of the court at Wellington (irrespective of where the deceased resided immediately before he or she died).

An application in solemn form under rule 27.6 and all documents relating to that application must be filed in the registry of the court nearest to where the deceased resided immediately before he or she died.

If the deceased did not reside in New Zealand when he or she died and his or her property is situated in only 1 place in New Zealand, the application and documents must be filed in the registry of the court nearest, by the most practicable route, to the place where his or her property is situated.

If the deceased did not reside in New Zealand when he or she died and his or her property is situated in more than 1 place in New Zealand, the application and documents must be filed in the registry of the court at Wellington or a registry specified under subclause (6).

If the deceased did not reside in New Zealand when he or she died and left no property in New Zealand, the application and documents must be filed in the registry of the court at Wellington or a registry specified under subclause (6).
If subclause (4) or (5) applies,—
the applicant may make an interlocutory application for an order specifying the registry of the court in which the application and documents are to be filed; and
the court may make an order specifying the registry.
If an application or a document is filed in the wrong registry of the court, the court may order the transfer of the application or document to the appropriate registry.

history.history-note: Rule 27.10: replaced, on 1 September 2017, by rule 25 of the High Court Rules 2016 Amendment Rules (No 2) 2017 (LI 2017/191).

para.text: This rule applies to a caveat under section 60 of the Administration Act 1969.
The caveat must be in form PR 10.
The caveat must be lodged with the Registrar of the court at Wellington.

history.history-note: Rule 27.11(3): replaced, on 4 June 2013, by rule 5 of the High Court Amendment Rules 2013 (SR 2013/128).

para.text: The court may accept any evidence that satisfies it of the death of a person whose estate is the subject of an application for a grant, unless no dead body has been identified as that of the person.
If no dead body has been identified as that of the person, the applicant must apply for leave to swear death.
The applicant applies by—
making an interlocutory application before filing an application for a grant; or
incorporating the application for leave to swear death in an application without notice under rule 27.4.
The applicant must file affidavits stating—
the circumstances under which the application is made; and
the facts from which the court is invited to infer death; and
whether or not the person’s life was insured and, if it was, the name and address of the insurer.
If the person’s life was insured,—
the applicant must serve notice of the application and copies of the affidavits on the insurer; and
